Unies par des relations économique et de voisinage, elles font la préparation et la vente de l’attièké (Semoule d’igname ou de patate sauvage). En plus elles font de la friandise de haricot, de mil etc.
Elles sont parténaires de l’institution SoroYiriwaso depuis maintenat 2 ans et sont à leur quatrième prêt solidaire(prêt de groupe).Tous les prêts précédents ont été correctement remboursés.
Le prêt actuel sera utilisé pour acheter, 240 kg de manioc avec les commercantes venant d’Odjéné (en république de la  Côte d’Ivoire), du poisson , de l’huile de l’oignon et du piment. Les autres ingrédints entrant dans la préparation de l’attièké sont achetés sur place au marché.
La clientèle est contituée de forains et des nombreux passagers qui transitent par Yanfolila en partance pour les républiques de la Guinée Conakry  ou   de la  Côte d’Ivoire.
La vente se fait au marché de Yanfolila sous des hangards aménagés à cet effet. Elles espèrent réaliser chacune un bénéfice hebdomadaire de 10.000 FCFA soit au minimum  40.000 FCFA par mois qui servira à rembourser les intérêts du prêt et assurer certaines dépenses de la famille comme l’éducation des enfants, la santé , l’habillement ...etc.
texts.en:
The four women of the Koly group (2 widows, 2 married) have an average age of 40 years, 4 children, and live in polygamous households in the Bounoukobougou quarter in the Yanfolila prefecture (the third administrative region in the Republic of Mali). United by economic and neighborly relationships, the women make and sell attièké (semolina flour made from yams or wild potatoes). They also make candies out of beans, millet, etc. They have been partners with the Soro Yiriwaso institution for two years and are now on their fourth solidarity (or group) loan. All of their previous loans were repaid in full. The current loan will be used to by 240 kg of cassavas with the merchants coming from Odjéné (in the Republic of Côte d’Ivoire), fish, oil onion, and peppers. The other ingredients used in making attièké are purchased on-site at the market. The client base is made up of stallkeepers and numerous passengers who pass through Yanfolila on their way to Conakry, Guinea or Côte d’Ivoire. They sell their products at the Yanfolila market underneath makeshift sheds designed for that purpose. They each hope to make a weekly profit of 10,000 FCFA or at least 40,000 FCFA per month which will be used to pay the interest on the loan and to take care of certain family expenses such as the children’s education, healthcare, clothing, etc.

Translated from French by Manuel Carreiro, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of food items

loans.name: 31- Nam Ngạn Group

texts.en:
This group consists of 5 people. They live in Nam Ngan ward, T. Hoa City. They want to borrow money to buy something to resell in the markets. Mrs Ngan is the group leader. She was born in 1977. Her husband is Mr. An, and he is 38 years old. They has a daughter in grade five. Other members of the group include the following:

Mrs T. Thuy was born in 1984, and her husband is Mr T. Van. He is 25 years old. They have a very small child. 

Mrs Nguyet has 2 children and her children are studying in school. 

Mrs Kim was born in 1956. Her husband is Mr Thuyet.

Mrs Mai borrows money to open a small restaurant, and her husband is Mr Tuong.

Mrs Phuong is 59 years old and her husband is Mr Truong. They have 3 children and their children stopped studying after they finished grade seven and now they lend money. Their mother wants to borrow from the Fund for T. Hoa Poor Women to open a small shop making photographs.

loans.use: Buying food & household items to resell

loans.name: Gatsirage Damien

texts.en:
Greetings from Damien G. in Kigali, the capital city of Rwanda! Damien is 57 years old, married with 3 children and two adopted children from the 1994 Genocide!

This client started his agricultural business in 2004 with a loan worth US$ 100 from Vision Finance Company. He has been paying his previous loans on time and he is currently on the 6th loan cycle. He grows various fruit such as passion fruit, avocados, oranges, pineapples, etc. Besides growing fruit, he also raises cows that produce milk and manure for his gardens.

He employs 4 people in his business and is looking for a loan worth 300,000 Frws to buy more manure to fertilize his gardens for fruit and to grow grass for his cows. He will be selling milk from the cows as added income. He is therefore requesting a loan worth 300,000 Frws. The loan term is 8 months, repaid monthly.

loans.use: To buy manure to fertilize his garden

loans.name: Che Comfort

texts.en:
Che Comfort B. is married with five children. She lives in Ntassen, just outside of Bamenda, Cameroon.  With this loan, Comfort plans to invest in her grocery store. Specifically, she will purchase rice, books, oil, soap, beer and other drinks.  
 
This is Comfort's second loan, She has been a member of GHAPE since 2007. She has a great deal of experience in her grocery store business. In fact, she manages the store alone. Over the years, her customers have become regular as they build a trusting relationship. She also feels that she has an excellent site for her business. 
 
The profit from this loan will be used to pay her children's school fees. She will also invest much of her profit back into her business. The rest will be used to clothe her children well, provide medical assistance to her family, and feed her family.  
 
The Grounded and Holistic Approach to People's Empowerment (GHAPE) is a non-profit NGO based in Bamenda, Cameroon. GHAPE works towards the empowerment of the poor and poverty alleviation through a highly multi-faceted approach. Every client is trained in business management, basic health, life skills, financial management, profits and losses, and family values. Clients are also required to contribute a small amount into a personal savings account; most clients save much more than the minimum requirement. GHAPE instils a sense of family and community within its clients and staff and has developed a strong bond of trust between the organization and its clients.

loans.use: 2 bags of rice, books, 5 tins of oil, 2 cartons of soap, beer and other drinks

loans.name: Erwt

texts.en: hgjmh

loans.use: wertwert

loans.name: Aiša

texts.en:
Aiša was born in 1958 and she lives in Zbije, a village outside Visoko in Bosnia. She is married to a construction worker and has two adult sons who live with her and help her in the fields. Her family`s income comes largely from selling vegetables in the local market. The vegetables include tomatoes, potatoes, onions and carrots. Aiša also raises chickens and sells chicken meat to support her family.

Aiša requests a loan of 1,200KM from Women for Women International to build a greenhouse. The greenhouse will allow her to grow vegetables in the late autumn and early spring, providing her family with a larger and more stable flow of income.

loans.use: To construct a greenhouse.

loans.name: Benkadi (Entente) Group

texts.fr:
Les membres de Benkadi sont toutes des femmes mariées ayant en moyenne de 37 ans et 3 enfants et vivant dans des familles traditionnelles élargies dans le quartier Dougoukoro de la ville de Yanfolila (une des préfectures de la troisième région administrative de la république du Mali).
Elles sont unies par les liens de voisinage et d’amitié. Ce groupe s’est spécialisée dans le secteur de la vente des tissus wax(tissus très prisés en Afrique) et des céréales.
Elles sont parténaires avec l’institution SoroYiriwaso depuis maintenat 2 ans et sont à leur quatrième prêt solidaire(prêt de groupe).Tous les prêts précédents ont été correctement remboursés. Ce prêt leur permettra d’acheter,  40 pièces de pagnes wax à Bamako auprès des grossistes du domaine et 1000 kg de céréales auprès de forains venant des villages environnants.
Ces pagnes  ainsi achetés sont découpés en  “trois pagnes”et vendus au comptant et en  détail dans les différents quartiers de Yanfolila et au marché. Ce commerce permet de générer 1250 FCFA de bénéfice par pièce vendue.Quant aux  vendeuses de céréales elles revendent au comptant en  détail et à crédit à une clientèle composée surtout de femmes.
Les membres de Benkadi espèrent réaliser chacune dans sa spécialité un bénéfice de 50.000 FCFA par mois qu’elles comptent utiliser pour payer les intérêts du prêt et aider les conjoints à subvenir aux dépenses de la famille. Les femmes  de ce groupe ambitionnent ouvrir des boutiques et des magasins de vente de céréales afin d’élargir la taille de la clientèle.
texts.en:
The members of Benkadi are all married women who, on average, are 37 years old and have 3 children. They live in extended traditional families in the Dougoukoro neighborhood in the city of Yanfolila (one of the prefectures of the third administrative region of the Republic of Mali). They are linked by bonds of neighborhood and friendship. This groups specializes in selling Wax pagne (a highly prized cloth in Africa) and cereals. They've been partnering with the Soro Yiriwaso institution for two years now and are seeking their fourth solidarity loan (group loan). All previous loans have been repaid without problems. This loan will enable them to buy 40 pieces of Wax pagne from wholesalers in Bamako, as well as 100 kg of cereals from itinerant merchants coming from the surrounding villages. The pagnes are then cut into "trois pagnes" ("three pagnes", i.e. the amount of fabric needed to make some woman outfits) and retailed for cash in the market and in the various neighborhoods in Yanfolila. The business results in a profit of XOF 1250 (ca US$ 2.40) per piece. The cereals are retailed to a mostly female clientele, for cash and on credit. The members of the Benkadi group hope to make, each in their speciality, a monthly profit of XOF 50'000 (ca US$ 100) that thy intend to use to repay the loan and help their husbands in providing for the family. The women of this group have the ambition to open cereals shops to broaden their clientele.

Translated from French by Patrick Stadelmann, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy Wax pagnes (highly prized cloth) and cereals

loans.name: Alma

texts.en:
Alma Ahmić was born in 1981 and she is from Visoka, a village in Bosnia. She is married and has a 6-year-old child. Her husband has a business as a carpenter, and sells custom-made wood products in the local market. Alma helps her husband in his woodshop, and also grows vegetables (potatoes, onions and carrots) which she sells for about 150KM/month (the equivalent of roughly $100USD/month).

Alma requests a loan of 600KM from Women for Women International, which she will use to buy raw materials for the woodshop.

loans.use: To purchase supplies for a woodshop.

loans.name: Gloriose

texts.en:
Greetings from Gloriose in Byumba, Rwanda! Gloriose is 44 years old and married with 6 children.

Gloriose started her business in 2006. She runs a shop selling different kind of clothes and women's shoes in Byumba Market. She needs a loan of 150,000 Rwf. This is the first time she is going to use the Vision Finance Company loans. She believes that once she gets this loan, her shop will become bigger because she is planning to buy men’s clothes, which are more desired in the market

Furthermore, she says that this loan will increase her profit, which will enable her to feed and pay the school fees for her children.

loans.use: To  buy men's clothing for re-sale in her shop

loans.name: Alice

texts.en:
Alice A. O. sells used children’s clothing in Rongo, Kenya. She has been doing so for 5 years and says that while business is okay, it could be better. Each month, Alice travels into the city of Nairobi twice in order to purchase the clothing she sells. She is only able to buy as much as her funds at the time allow, which usually limits her purchases. She would like to be able to afford to buy larger amounts of inventory during each trip, as it is cheaper to purchase the used clothing in bulk.

Alice is a widow and is the sole breadwinner for her 3 children. She is requesting a loan of 10,000 Kenyan Schillings in order to buy the used children’s clothing in bulk from Nairobi, thus increasing her inventory and saving her money.

loans.use: To buy used children's clothing

loans.name: 41-Quảng Hưng Group

texts.en:
Loan Group 41 consists of 5 poor women who live in Village 3, Quang Hung Commune in Thanh Hoa City.  Thanh Hoa City is the provincial capital of Thanh Hoa province, one of the poorest provinces in Vietnam. It is located approximately 150 kilometers south of Hanoi, the capital of Vietnam. 

Mrs Chung is the lead borrower of the group.  She is 37 years old, and has a husband and children. During the day, she works in the Le Mom Industrial Zone.  

As with her previous loans, all of which have been fully repaid, Mrs Chung will use the funds from this loan to buy and raise pigs and chickens. Her share of the loan will probably be sufficient to buy 3 pigs and 50 chicken. With the profits from selling eggs and the animals themselves, she intends to improve her family’s life.  

The loan will be split equally between all five borrowers. The other borrowers in the group will use their share of the loan for similar purposes.
   
Mrs. Hoa is borrowing 2.761.200 Vietnam dong (~ $163 USD) to buy cows.
Mrs. Duong is borrowing to buy food and vegetables for pigs.
Mrs. Dam is borrowing to buy chicken and ducks.
Mrs. Huong is borrowing to buy pigs.

loans.use: Buying and raising animals

loans.name: Benkan (Concorde Group

texts.fr:
Constitué de femmes mariées ayant une moyenne d’age de 25 ans et 2 enfants, les membres du groupe Benkan, vivent avec leur mari, les enfants et autres parents dans des familles traditionnelles élargies dans le village de Marka-Coungo préfecture de Dioila (relevant de Koulikoro deuxième région administrative de la république du Mali). 
Unies par des relations de mariages, ces femmes se sont spécialisées dans l’achat et la vente de condiments alimentaires. Elles sont à leur septième prêt solidaire (prêt de groupe) avec le programme crédit de Soro Yiriwaso et tous les prêts précédents ont été correctement rembourses.
Elles veulent acheter avec ce prêt, 500kg de sel de cuisine, 50kg de concentrée de tomate, 100kg de poissons fumés, 400 kg d’oignons et divers autres condiments dans les marchés de Bamako (capitale du Mali).
Elles effectuent leur vente dans le marché de Marka-Coungo au comptant en détail et quelques fois à crédit à une clientèle essentiellement féminine
Elles envisagent réaliser chacune un bénéfice par cycle de 20 000FCFA qui servira à payer les intérêts du prêt et épauler les maris à supporter les charges de la famille (les frais scolaires, de santé et de nourriture).
texts.en:
The Benkan group is made up of married women with an average age of 25 and two children. These women live in traditional extended families with their husband, children and other relatives in the village of Marka-Coungo in the Dioila prefecture (part of Koulikoro, the second administrative region of the Republic of Mali). Related through marriage, these women specialize in buying and selling condiments. They are on their seventh solidarity loan (group loan) with the Soro Yiriwaso (Kiva Field Partner) loan program, and all their previous loans have been fully repaid. With this loan, they want to buy 500kg of cooking salt, 50kg of tomato concentrate, 100kg of smoked fish, 400kg of onions and various other condiments in the markets of Bamako (capital of Mali). They retail their goods in the Marka-Coungo market for cash, or sometimes for credit, to a predominantly female clientele. They expect to make a profit per cycle of 20,000 FCFA ($40) each, which will allow them to pay off the loan interest and help their husbands with the family expenses (school fees, healthcare costs and food bills).

Translated from French by Alison Dent, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy and sell condiments

loans.name: Kassem

texts.en:
Kamal is a 31 year-old married man with three children. Living in South Lebanon in the town of Burj Rahal, Kamal has worked as a painter since 2000. Working on a freelance basis, he manages part of house projects in Burj Rahal and its surroundings. With the help of several microloans, he managed to expand his business by buying tools and a pick-up for easier transport to the houses he works within.

Today, Kamal requests a loan of $1,200 to buy equipment such as scaffolds and wood boards.

loans.use: To buy scaffolds and other equipment.

loans.name: Benkola (Accord) Group

texts.fr:
Les membres du groupe sont en majorité des femmes mariées ayant une moyenne d’âge de 20 ans et 1 enfant. Elles vivent dans des familles traditionnelles polygames avec leur mari et enfants dans le village de Marka-Coungo (Région de Koulikoro République du Mali). 
Les femmes du groupe BENKOLA se sont connues par des relations de mariages et sont spécialisées dans le commerce des produits de beauté.
Elles sont à leur huitième prêt solidaire (prêt de groupe) avec Soro Yiriwaso et tous les prêts précédents ont été correctement remboursés. 
Ce nouveau prêt servira à acheter, 300 boites de pommade et crème, 200 bouteilles parfums de différentes qualités et d’autres effets pour le maquillage.
 Elles s’approvisionnent exclusivement à Bamako (capitale de la république du Mali) auprès de grossiste de ce domaine. Elles reviennent vendre les produits dans les marchés de Marka-Coungo et de Fana au comptant en détail et à crédit à une clientèle essentiellement constituée de femmes. 
Elles espèrent chacune réaliser un bénéfice par cycle de 30 000 FCFA par mois qui sera utilisé pour subvenir aux besoins de la famille (frais de nourriture, sanitaire et scolaires des enfants.
texts.en:
The members of the group BENKOLA are mostly married women who average 20 years of age and one child. They live in traditional polygamous families with their husband and children in the village of Marka-Coungo (Koulikoro region, Republic of Mali).

The women of the group know one another via marital ties and are specialized in the commerce of beauty products. They are on their eighth solidarity loan (group loan) with Soro Yiriwaso. All of their preceding loans have been correctly repaid. This new loan will serve to buy: 300 jars of ointment and cream, 200 bottles of perfume of different grades, and other beauty care products.

They get their supplies exclusively in Bamako (capital of Mali) from wholesalers in this field. They come back to sell the goods at the marketplaces of Marka-Coungo and Fana, cash or credit accepted, to customers essentially composed of women. They each hope to realize a profit of 30,000 francs CFA per cycle each month that will be used to cover family expenses (cost of food, hygiene, and schooling for the children).

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy ointments, creams, and other beauty products

loans.name: Darine

texts.en:
Darine A. S. has owned a mini-market in Jnah, a suburb of Beirut, since 1996. A mother of three, she opened this small business to help her husband with the family's income and to pay for their children's schooling. Her mini-market is situated in a busy area, so she has been able, over the years, to have a growing number of clients pass by her shop and buy all type of food products. 

Today she requests a loan of $1200 to buy more inventory and continue to cater to her clientele.

loans.use: Buy Inventory

loans.name: Danaya (La Confiance) Group

texts.fr:
Constituée exclusivement de femmes mariées, les membres du groupe Danaya ont en moyenne 20 ans et 2 enfants. Elles vivent dans des familles nucléaires dans la sous- préfecture de Fana (deuxième région administrative de Mali). Danaya fait des activités diverses et variées qui va de la fabrication de boissons non alcoolisées à partir de jus en poudre et des plantes locales, à l’achat et la vente de pagnes wax (tissus très prisés en Afrique), de tapis etc.
Pour préparer le jus de zinzimbre, elles écrasent le zinzimbre pour la rendre pâteux.  Pour 2 (deux) kilogramme de pâte de zinzimbre on ajoute 10 (dix) litres d’eau, 5 kilos de sucre et des aromes pour bien les malaxer. Après on filtre le mélange à l’aide d’un tamis filtre pour le mettre dans des sachets qui seront mis au frais dans un réfrigérateur avant la vente proprement dite.
Dans le souci d’agrandir la taille de leurs activités, elles ont décidé de collaborer avec le programme crédit de Soro Yiriwaso avec lequel elles sont à leur cinquième prêt de groupe (prêt solidaire).  Tous les prêts précédents ont été correctement remboursés.
Ce présent prêt sera utilisé pour acheter, 20 tapis de quatre (4) mettre carré et 50 pièces de pagnes wax,  200 kg de sucre, 50kg de dah, 50kg de zinzimbre, des colorants et des sachets plastiques. 
Les membres du groupe Danaya qui font la vente de pagnes wax et de tapis s’approvisionnent dans le marché de Bobo Dioulasso (au Burkina Faso). Ces pagnes wax (préablement découpés en trois pagnes) sont vendus ainsi que le tapis au comptant et à crédit payable mensuellement. Quant aux fabricantes de boissons non alcoolisées, elles se ravitaillent dans le marché de Fana et vendent dans le même marché en détail au comptant à une clientèle généralement composée de femmes, de forains et d’enfants Elles comptent réaliser chacune 25000 FCFA de bénéfice par cycle qui servira à aider les maris à supporter les charges scolaires des enfants.
texts.en:
The married women who make up the Danaya group have an average age of 20 years and two children. They live in nuclear families in the Fana sous-prefecture (second administrative region of Mali). The Danaya group participates in diverse activities, from the production of non-alcoholic beverages and powdered juice, and the selling of local plants to the purchase and selling of pagne wax (a highly-prized fabric in Africa), as well as rugs. To prepare ginger juice, they crush the ginger into a paste. For two kilograms of ginger paste, 10 litres of water, 5 kilograms of sugar, and flavoring are added. Afterwards the mixture is filtered with a sieve and then put into packets which will be placed into a refrigerator before they are sold. Wanting to increase the size of their business, the women have decided to collaborate with the Soro Yiriwaso loan program with which they are on their fifth group (or solidarity) loan. All of their previous loans were repaid in full. The current loan will be used to purchase 20 rugs measuring four square meters each and 50 pieces of pagne wax, 200 kilograms of sugar, 50 kilograms of dah (dried hibiscus leaves), 50 kilograms of ginger, colorings, and plastic packets. The members of the Danaya group who sell the pagne wax and the rugs get their stock at the Bobo Dioulasso market (in Burkina Faso). These pagne wax (precut into three pieces) as well as the rugs are sold for cash and on credit with monthly payments. As for the makers of the non-alcoholic beverages, they stock up at the Fana market and sell their products at the same market at retail prices for cash to a client base comprised mainly of women, stallkeepers, and children. They each hope to make 25,000 FCFA in profit per cycle (which is an average of four weeks) which will be used to help their husbands pay for their children’s educational expenses.

Translated from French by Manuel Carreiro, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of pagne wax, rugs, and ingredients to make non-alcoholic beverages (from sugar, powdered juice, ginger, dah packets, flavorings, etc)

loans.name: Abass

texts.en: Abass is a 27-year-old young man living in Chyah, a suburban area of Beirut. Previously working as a hairdresser, Abass decided to have his own business and opened the 'Just Hair' Salon in 2003. Catering to clients from all neighborhoods, Abass is managing his salon well and intends on improving his services. Today he requests a loan of $1000 to ameliorate the salon's decor and give a relaxing atmosphere to his clients.

loans.use: To improve the salon's decor

loans.name: 17-Nam Ngạn Group

texts.vi:
Chị N. Thị Đỗ sinh năm 1950. Gia dìng chị sống ở Phường Nam Ngạn, Thành Phố Thanh Hoá. Chồng chị đã mất, chị có 2 người con, hiện tạichị sống với con trai út. Hai con của chị là lao động tự do. Chị vay vốn để đầu tư vào việc trồng rau. Binh quân thu nhập một ngày của chị là 50.000 VND. Sáng sớm chị hái rau bán cất cho các nhà buôn ngoài ra chị còn nuôi thêm gà, vịt, lợn. Chị rát thích cách thức vay vốn và hoàn trả của Quỹ Thanh Hoá. Chị muốn vay mức 2.442.600 VND. các thành viên khác trong nhóm:
Chị N. Thị Tố Hảo có 4 người con, 2 con trai và 2 con gái. Chồng chị đã mất. 3 người con của Chị đã lập gia đình. Hiện tại chị đang ở với con trai cả. Chi vay vốn để buôn bán nhỏ
Chị Truột sinh năm 1964, chị có 3 người con gái và cả 3 người con của chi đều đang học. Anh chị vay vốn về đầu tư vào việc chăn nuôi và ngoài ra chị còn dùng tiền vay vốn để mua vôi ,cát và bán lại cho mọi người trong phố.
Chị Yến sinh năm 1977. Chồng chị là Công. anh chị có 1 con đang còn nhỏ. Chị vay vốn để buôn bán bánh mỳ, hạt dẻ, hạt bầu, hạt dưa
Chị Hoa sinh năm 1978. Chi vay vốn về để buôn bán nhỏ.
texts.en:
Mrs N. Thị Đỗ was born in 1950. She lives in Nam Ngạn district, town of Thanh Hoá. Her husband passed away. She has 2 children, the younger one is still living with her. They are both free lance laborers. She is seeking a loan to cultivate vegetables. Her income is about 50.000 VND a day. Everyday, early in the morning she would go to the field to pick vegetables then sells to the vendors. She also raises poultry and pigs. She likes the loan program from "Thanh Hoá". She is requesting a loan of 2.442.600 VND. Other members in her group are:
  • Mrs N. Thị Tố Hảo, she has 2 sons and 2 daughters. Her husband passed. She is living with her oldest son, the other 3 are married. She sells basic goods.
  • Mrs Truột, she was born in 1964. She has 3 daughters who are still in school. She and her husband are seking a loan to incest in their pig raising business. She would also use part of the loan to buy sand and lime to resell.
  • Mrs Yến, she was born in 1977. Her husband is Mr Công. They have a young child. She sells bread, chestnut, melon seeds.
  • Mrs Hoa, she was born in 1978. She sells basic goods.

    • Translated from Vietnamese by Khang Ho-Si, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: cultivate vegetables

loans.name: Adizatou

texts.fr:
Madame Adizatou Traoré est agée de 37 ans, mariée et mère de 6 enfants , elle vit dans une famille nucleaire avec son mari et ses enfants dans le quartier Nangosso de la préfecture de Koutiala(troisième région administrative de la république du Mali).
Issue d’une famille de commerçants, madame Adizatou  Traoré a été très vite initiée aux activités génératrices de revenues (car ses parents n’ont jamais voulu qu’elle fréquente l’école). Après une longue phase d’apprentissage auprès de sa grand-mère, elle décida de se spécialiser dans le commerce de céréales depuis maintenant 10 ans. La demande de la clientèle est très importante à cause du fait que le riz constitue un des aliments de base au Mali.
Dans le souci de mieux satisfaire cette clientèle, elle décida de faire recours à l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso depuis  2004. Avec une expérience de 6 prêts en solidaire de groupe  (prêt de groupe) bien remboursés ,elle est à son 2eme prêt en individuel dont le 1er s’est terminé sans difficulté.
Avec ce prêt Madame Adizatou Traoré compte acheter une tonne de riz à Niono (une des plus grandes zone de culture du riz en  république du Mali) auprès des producteurs des casiers rizicoles.
Elle vend au grand marché de Koutiala à une clientèle essentiellement constituée de femmes et d’hommes, au comptant, en détali et à crédit. L’activité est très rentable et a une marge bénéficiaire importante si bien qu’elle compte réaliser un bénéfice de 70.000FCFA par cycle. Ce bénéfice sera utilisé pour rembourser les intérêts du prêt et contribuer aux charges de la famille. Elle souhaite prochainement ouvrir un magasin de stockage des céréales au grand marché de koutiala .
texts.en:
Madame Adizatou Traoré is 37 years old, married and has six children. She lives in a nuclear family with her husband and their children in the Nangosso district of Koutiala prefecture (third administrative region of the Republic of Mali). Born into a family of tradesmen, Madame Traoré was initiated into revenue-generating activities at a very young age (her parents never wanted her to attend school). After a long apprenticeship at her grandmother’s side, she decided to specialize in trading cereals ten years ago now. There is a very heavy demand from her clientele because rice constitutes one of Mali’s basic foods. Anxious to better satisfy her clientele, in 2004 she decided to turn to the microfinance organization Soro Yiriwaso (Kiva Field Partner). With an experience of six solidarity loans (group loans) fully repaid, she is on her second individual loan; the first having been completed with no problem. With this loan Madame Traoré intends to buy a ton of rice at Niono (one of the largest rice-growing areas in the Republic of Mali) from the growers in the rice fields.She retails the rice for cash or credit at the big market in Koutiala to a clientele consisting of both men and women. This is a very lucrative operation, with a large profit margin, such that she expects to make a profit of 70,000 FCFA ($150) per cycle. This profit will be used to repay the loan interest and contribute to the family expenses. Soon Madame Traoré hopes to open a small warehouse for the cereals in the Koutiala market.

Translated from French by Alison Dent, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To purchase rice

loans.name: Iskandar

texts.en:
A. Iskandar is 53 years old. He is married with six children. Iskandar is a market vendor. He is selling clothing for men and women in the local market of Dushanbe city called Panjsher. Over four years of working at the market, Iskandar already has enough experience to do his work successfully and has clients who always come to him. Iskandar has a large and friendly family who always try to help each other. Thus his son is also engaged in this business. Iskandar wishes his children to get a good education, allowing them to have a better chance to succeed in the future - this is what makes his sacrifice worthwhile.

As his children are growing up their expenses are rising accordingly, so in order to increase his business Iskandar is requesting a loan of 2500 Somoni (US$750). He will use the loan to purchase merchandise so he can offer a wider selection to his customers and increase his income. With the rotation of supplies in his business, he plans to repay the loan within six months.

The well-being of Iskandar’s family and his business are in your hands. Iskandar and his family are sincerely grateful for your support.

loans.use: Purchasing the new goods for selling.

loans.name: Bintou

texts.fr:
Autochtone du quartier de Koulikoro de la préfecture de koutiala (troisième région administrative de la république du Mali),Madame Bintou est agée de 31 ans et vit dans une famille monogame avec son mari et ses 3 enfants. Elle abandonna très tôt les études pour se consacrer aux activités génératrices de revenus notamment l’achat et la vente des articles  de fête (sacs à mains, habits pour enfants, soutien gorge etc). Elle a appris ce commerce  auprès de sa  mère qui est une grossiste de tissus et divers dépuis  des décennies.  Avec ses 15 ans d’expériences elle est très sollicitée et appréciée dans la ville de Koutiala surtout à l’approche des fêtes et de la  rentrée  des classes où elle reçoit beaucoup de commandes.
Elle décida de faire recours à l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso il ya de cela  3 ans.. Après 4 prêts solidaires (prêt de groupe) et un prêt individuel, tous correctement remboursé, elle est à son 2eme prêt individuel.  Madame Bintou Dembélé  compte acheter avec ce prêt,  5 balles de sacs à main à Bobo Dioilasso au  Burkina Faso et souvent à Lomé (en république du Togo) auprès de commerçants grossistes. Elle vend ses marchandises à crédit ou au comptant dans la ville de Koutiala et dans les foires hebdomadaires des villages environnants  à une clientèle composée  de femmes et hommes. 
Elle compte réaliser un bénéfice de 80.000FCFA  par cycle qui sera utilisé pour augmenter son fonds de commerce, et rembourser les intérêts de son prêt..
texts.en:
A native of the Koulikoro region of Koutiala prefecture (Mali’s third administrative district), Bintou is 31 years old, and lives with her husband and three children in a monogamous household. She quit school early to devote herself to income-generating activities, notably the buying and selling of formalwear (handbags, children’s clothing, bras, et cetera). Bintou learnt her trade from her mother, who for decades has dealt wholesale in fabric and other items. With 15 years of experience, Bintou is highly sought after and appreciated in the town of Koutiala, especially with the approaching holiday season and return to classes, a time when she receives many orders. Three years ago, Bintou decided to turn to the Soro Yiriwaso microfinance institution. After four group loans and one individual loan, all properly repaid, she is requesting her second individual loan. With this loan Bintou plans to buy five lots of handbags from wholesale merchants in Bobo Dioilasso, Burkina Faso and Lomé, Togo. Bintou sells her merchandise on credit or for cash to both men and women in the city of Koutiala and at the weekly trade fairs in nearby towns. Over the course of the loan cycle, she hopes to make a profit of $175 (80,000 XOF African francs), which she will use to grow her business and repay the interest on her loan.

Translated from French by Joyce ., Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of handbags

loans.name: Mayrambi

texts.en:
J. Mayrambi is 42 years old. She is married and the mother of five children. Mayrambi's lack of a stable job and the slow productivity of her husband's business as an independent taxi driver didn't leave enough money to pay the expenses of the home and of her little daughter, so Mayrambi decided to start her own business nine years ago selling the fabrics of the national dresses.

Little by little she has made her business grow and by offering her clients to pay in installments her orders are getting bigger. Now her business is running normally, but she would like to continue bettering herself (and her business) so her situation will be stable in the future. She is asking for a loan of 2000 Somoni (US$600) that she will pay back in nine months. With this money, Mayrambi will be able to buy seasonal fabrics for the national dresses.

The power to help her business grow is in your hands.

loans.use: Purchasing of seasonal fabrics to increase the range of goods.

loans.name: Korotoumou

texts.fr:
Madame  Korotoumou Traoré est âgée de 31 ans, mariée et mère de 3 enfants vivant dans une famille polygame avec son mari, sa coépouse et leurs enfants dans le quartier Hamdallaye de la préfecture de Koutiala(troisième région administrative de la république).
Comme la plupart de sa génération elle n’a pas fréquenté l’école et s’est très vite intérressée aux activités génératrices de revenu , notamment  la préparation et la vente des nourritures qu’elle a apprise  auprès d’une amie il ya de cela 10 ans. Elle est très bien sollicitée surtout  par les élèves en cette période de rentrée scolaire. 
Pour élargir son activité Korotoumou décida de collaborer avec Soro Yiriwaso depuis  2 ans . Après 3 prêts  solidaires (prêt de groupe) bien remboursés, elle est à son 2eme prêt  individuel dont le 1er prêt aussi a été correctement remboursé.
Elle compte acheter, 50 kg de pomme de terre,  1 sacs de banane plantin et une importantes quantités de divers condiments alimentaires au marché de Koutiala auprès de grossistes. Elle vend ses nourritures aux abords d’une école au quartier Koko dans la ville de koutiala.Elle a une clientèle essentiellement composée d’élèves et de gourmets.
Elle compte réaliser un bénéfice de 60.000FCFA par mois qu’elle envisage d’utiliser pour rembourser les intérêts du prêt et participer aux dépenses quotidiennes de la famille.  Elle  ambitionne ouvrir un restaurant dans la ville de Koutiala.
texts.en:
Mrs. Korotoumou Traoré is 31 years old, married and the mother of three children. She lives in a polygamous family with her husband, co-spouse and their children in the Hamdallaye neighborhood of Koutiala prefecture (the Republic’s third administrative region). While, like most of her generation, she did not go to school, she quickly became interested in income-generating activities, particularly the preparation and selling of food, which she learned from a friend 10 years ago. She is much in demand, especially by school students now that classes have started up again. To expand her business, Korotoumou decided two years ago to join Soro Yiriwaso. After three solidarity loans (group loans) that she repaid in full, she is on her second individual loan, having repaid the first also in full. She wants to buy 50 kg of potatoes, one bag of plantain bananas and large quantities of spices from wholesalers at the market in Koutiala. She sells her food outside a school in the Koko neighborhood of Koutiala. Most of her customers are schoolchildren and people who enjoy good food. She expects to make a profit of CFA 60,000 per month that she plans to use to repay the interest on the loan and contribute towards the everyday expenses of her family. Her ambition is to open a restaurant in the town of Koutiala.

Translated from French by Sarah Llewellyn, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy food supplies

loans.name: Zafar

texts.en:
K. Zafar is 27 years old. He is married with two kids. Zafar is a market vendor selling men’s jeans, shirts, shoes and other clothes in the local market of Dushanbe city. Over five years of working at the market Zafar already has enough experience to do his work successfully and has clients who always come to him. Zafar is trying to satisfy the needs of clients with various tastes and income levels. Zafar’s kids are small now but already today he is working hard in order to give them a good education and to make them happy.

Today Zafar is planning to increase his working capital in order to purchase new goods for selling. For this purpose he requests 4000 Somoni (US$1200) for the term of 9 nine months. Zafar promises to repay the loan promptly and thanks all for supporting him.

Your generosity can change his live and the life of his family. Be an important part of the growth of Zafar’s business.

loans.use: Purchasing additional inventory for selling.

loans.name: Barno

texts.en:
M. Barno is 42 years old. She is an experienced business woman and the loving mother of four children. Barno is a well-known seamstress in her community, where she has been working for more than seven years. She rents a tailoring shop and also has her own sewing machine at her home. Her daughter also is engaged in this business. In this way, she constantly adds new clients and has seen her business grow.

Now she is requesting a loan of 2000 Somoni (US$600) for the term of nine months for purchasing the new modern fabrics for sewing the national dresses. You can help improve the quality of life of her family. Barno and her daughter are grateful for your generosity and support.

loans.use: Purchasing of the new modern fabrics for sewing the national dresses.

loans.name: Naïda

texts.fr:
Madame Naîda D. a 51 ans,  mariée et mère de 2 enfants vivant dans une famille polygame avec son mari, sa coepouse et leurs enfants dans le quartier Lafiala de la préfecture de Koutiala ( troisième région administrative de la république du Mali)
Dès son jeune âge elle fut initiée(par sa mère)aux activitée génératrices de revenus notamment le commerce de vêtements d’enfants. Avec ses trentes ans d’expériences dans le secteur du vêtement, elle maitrise parfaitement les tenants et aboutissants de ce domaine, ce qui lui vaut aujourd’hui dans la ville de Koutiala, une réputation et une notorieté très enviable.  Elle est trés bien sollicitée  lors des céremonies sociales et des fêtes.
Pour satisfaire sa clientèle de plus en plus croissante,  elle decida d’intégrer le programme crédit de l‘institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso depuis  4 ans.  Après avoir correctement remboursés les  4 prêts  solidaires (prêt de groupe) et les 4 prêts individuels, elle est à son 5 eme prêt en individuel.
Elle compte acheter avec ce prêt,  100 habits pour enfants à Bamako (capitale de la république du Mali) et parfois sur place à Koutiala auprès des grands commerçants grossistes. Elle vend ses marchandises au grand marché de Koutiala à une clientèle conctituée de femmes et hommes à crédit et au comptant.. Elle compte réaliser un bénéfice mensuel de 75.000FCFA qu’elle envisage d’utiliser pour rembourser les intérets du prêt et élargir son activité.
texts.en:
Mrs. Naîda D. is 51 years old, married, and has two children She lives in a polygamous family with her husband, her co-wife, and their children in the Lafiala quarter in the Koutiala prefecture (third administrative region of the Republic of Mali). Starting at a very young age, she participated (thanks to her mother) in income-generating activities, notably the selling of children’s clothing. With thirty years of experience in the clothing business, she has perfectly mastered the ins and outs of this field, which has given her an enviable reputation and fame in the city of Koutiala. She is often hired for social ceremonies and parties. In order to meet the needs of her ever-growing client base, she has been with the Soro Yiriwaso loan program institution for four years. After having repaid four previous solidarity (or group) loans, as well as four individual loans, she is now on her fifth individual loan. With this loan she hopes to buy 100 children’s outfits in Bamako (capital of the Republic of Mali). Sometimes she also purchases outfits on-site in Koutiala from large commercial wholesalers. She sells her merchandise, on credit and for cash, at the large market in Koutiala to both men and women. She hopes to make a monthly profit of 75,000 FCFA which she hopes to use to pay off the interest on the loan and to increase the size of her business.

Translated from French by Manuel Carreiro, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of children's outfits

loans.name: Kumri

texts.en:
M. Kumri is 53 years old. She is married and the loving mother of four children. Kumri owns a successful clothing and shoe sales business located at the Sakhovat market in Dushanbe, Tajikistan. She has been doing this business for about 13 years. Her business has benefited from a good sales location and constant demand for her products. Kumri tries to offer good prices to her customers while still making a profit. A normal monthly income from her business is around 1500 Somoni.

Kumri has requested a loan of 2500 Somoni (US$750) for a term of nine months to increase her product inventory. This is a busy time for many market vendors as the cold season is coming and everyone is preparing for winter season. By purchasing additional inventory, Kumri will be better prepared to meet increased demand and earn a good income.

We believe her perseverance and natural liveliness will help her continue to succeed in her trade and repay this loan on time.

loans.use: To increase her product inventory.

loans.name: Rokia

texts.fr:
Madame Rokia Traoré est agée de 43 ans mariée et mère de 7 enfants et vit dans une famille traditionnelle élargie avec son mari, ses coépouses et leurs enfants dans le quartier Koulikoro de la préfecture de Koutiala(troisième région administrative de la république du Mali).
Dès son jeune age elle s’est intéressée aux activités génératrices de revenus notamment le commerce. C’est son mari qui lui a donné l’idée de se  spécialiser dans la l’achat vente des fruits et cela depuis 20 ans. 
Elle est à son deuxième prêt individuel après 4 prêts solidaires (prêt de groupe) tous correctement bien remboursés..  
Avec ce prêt Madame  Rokia Traoré compte acheter, 10 paniers de bananes,  30 sacs d’orange et autres fruits auprès des paysans producteurs de Sikasso. Elle effectue sa vente au grand marché de Koutiala au comptant et à crédit à une clientèle constituée de femmes et d’hommes.
Elle compte réaliser un bénéfice de 70.000FCFA par mois qu’elle envisage utiliser pour rembourser les intérêts du prêt et aider son mari à subvenir aux  dépenses scolaires des enfants. Madame Rokia souhaite recevoir des formations sur la technique de conservation des fruits et légumes afin de mieux rentabiliser son entreprise.
texts.en:
Madame Rokia Traoré is 43 years old, married, and the mother of seven. She lives in a traditional extended family with her husband, her co-wives, and their children in the Koulikoro district of Koutiala Prefecture (third administrative region of the Republic of Mali). From an early age, she got interested in income-generating work, notably commerce. It was her husband who gave her the idea to specialize in buying and selling fruit, which she has been doing for twenty years.

Ms. Traoré is on her second individual loan after having correctly repaid four solidarity loans (group loans). With this loan, she intends to buy 10 baskets of bananas, 30 sacks of oranges, and other fruit from peasant producers of Sikasso. She makes her sales at the grand marketplace of Koutiala, cash or credit accepted, to customers composed of women and men.

Her intention is to realize a profit of 70,000 francs CFA per month that she envisions using to cover the loan interest and to assist her husband with covering the costs of schooling the children. She wishes to receive information on the techniques of preserving fruits and vegetables in order to make her enterprise more profitable.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Achat  des fruits et légumes .

loans.name: Zulpi

texts.en:
M. Zulpi is 42 years old. She is married and has four children. Zulpi has her own sewing machine at her home and she has been providing tailoring services for seven years. At the same time she is baking different kinds of cake and tajik pie called sambusa, reselling them to groceries, market stands and local neighbors in her community. Her daughter helps her with the business.

Zulpi is telling us that day by day her children are growing up and accordingly their expenses are rising, too. She always dreamed of her children being well educated and she is doing all her best to realize her dream, so she is very motivated to succeed in her daily and weekly sales goals.

Now Zulpi feels that with additional capital she can increase her sales and profits. For this reason she is requesting a loan of 2000 Somoni (US$600) for a term of nine months. She wants to buy necessary products for baking different kinds of cake.

Let’s get behind this dedicated mother to make her dreams become reality.

loans.use: Purchasing of the necessary products for baking.

loans.name: Sanata

texts.fr:
Enfant d’une famille de nomade spécialisée dans les activités de pêches, Sanata Djiré a été très tôt initiée aux activités génératrices de revenus par ses parents.. Après une longue phase d’apprentissage, elle décida de se spécialiser dans le commerce de poissons fumés. Aujourd’hui âgée de 48 ans Madame Sanata Djiré est dans un régime polygamique et vit avec son époux et ses 4 enfants (dont une fille et trois garçons) dans sa propre maison dans le quartier Hamdallaye de la préfecture de Koutiala (troisième région administrative de la république du Mali). 
 Avec une expérience de 18 ans elle est très sollicitée et appréciée dans les foires hebdomadaires des villages environnants.
Elle est en relation avec l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso depuis 3 ans. Après 4 prêts solidaires (prêt de groupe) et un prêt individuel, tous correctement bien remboursés, elle est à son deuxième prêt individuel.
Ce prêt sera utilisé pour acheter, 10 gros paniers de poissons fumés dans la région de Mopti auprès des pêcheurs (Bozos et Somonos) pour les stocker et les vendre en détail. Les ventes sont effectuées au comptant en gros et en détail, dans le marché de poissons de la ville de Koutiala, et dans les foires hebdomadaires des villages environnants à une clientèle constituée de revendeurs, de ménagères et de restaurateurs. 
Elle compte réaliser un bénéfice mensuel de 60 000 FCFA, qui sera utilisé pour payer les intérêts du prêt, subvenir aux dépenses de la famille et le reste pour renforcer le fonds de commerce.
texts.en:
A child from a nomadic family specialized in fishing, Sanata Djiré was, at a very early age, initiated into income-generating work by her parents. After a long apprenticeship, she decided to become specialized in the commerce of smoked fish. Today, she is 48 years old and in a polygamous arrangement, living with her husband and four children (one girl and three boys) in her own house in the Hamdallaye district of Koutiala Prefecture (third administrative region of the Republic of Mali). With eighteen years of experience, she is in great demand and highly valued at the weekly fairs of the surrounding villages. She has had an association with the micro-finance institution Soro Yiriwaso for three years. After four solidarity loans (group loans) and an individual loan, all correctly repaid, she is on her second individual loan. This loan will be used to buy 10 large baskets of smoked fish in the Mopti region from fishermen (Bozos and Somonos) in order to stock up and to make retail sales, in bulk and for cash, at the fish market of the city of Koutiala and at the weekly fairs nearby to customers composed of retailers, homemakers, and restauranteurs. She intends to realize a monthly profit of 60,000 francs CFA, which will be used to cover the loan interest, to provide for the family, and the rest to boost working capital.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy smoked fish

loans.name: Zulaykho

texts.en:
N. Zulaykho is 20 years old and single. She is running her own business for two years. Zulaykho sells bath towels and bed-clothes in the store which is located in one of the intensively inhabited parts of the city. She began her business in order to have an independent income and to support her parents.

Zulaykho is very nice and polite and has many clients. The business is quite stable and serves as a significant source of income for the family.

Now she requests 2500 Somoni (US$750) in order to increase the range of goods. Zulaykho is planning to pay the loan completely in six months. She promises to be accurate with the paying and thanks everyone for their support.

loans.use: Purchasing of bath towels and bed-clothes to increase the range of goods.

loans.name: Sanata

texts.fr:
Habitante du quartier Hamdallaye de la préfecture de Koutiala(troisième région administrative de la république du Mali),Madame Sanata Traoré est agée de 25 ans, mariée et mère de 2  enfants. En instance de divorce, elle vit actuellement chez son père. Sanata a prématurement abandonné les études pour des raisons sociales pour se lancer dans les activités génératrices de revenu notamment la vente des tissus qu’elle a apprise auprès de sa mère depuis son jeune âge. Elle a six ans d’expérience et maitrise bien son activité.  
Dans sa recherche de ressources financières complémentaire afin de satisfaire sa clientèle de plus en plus croissante et exigeante, elle decida d’intégrer le programme crédit de l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso avec lequel elle est a son premier prêt  individuel.  
Avec ce prêt elle compte faire des voyages  à Lomé ( capitale de la république du Togo) pour acheter des tissus brodés. Elle effectue sa vente au grand marché de Koutiala à une clientèle essentiellement feminine. La vente se fait en détail, en gros, au comptant et à crédit payable mensuellement.. Elle compte réaliser un bénéfice de 70.000FCFA par mois qu’elle envisage utiliser pour rembourser les intérêts du prêt de Soro yirawaso et  faire face aux  dépenses  de ses 2 enfants.
Dans ses perspectives, elle envisage d’ouvrir une boutique de vente de tissus au grand marché de Koutiala.
texts.en:
Living in the Hamdallaye district of Koutiala Prefecture (third administrative region of the Republic of Mali), Ms. Sanata Traoré, age 25, is married and the mother of two. About to go though a divorce, she is currently living at her father's place. She had prematurely quit school for social reasons in order to get started earning an income, notably in selling fabrics, something she learned from her mother at a young age. She has six years of experience and has a good command of her business.

In her search for supplemental financial resources, for satisfying her demanding and burgeoning customer base, she decided to join the loan program of the micro-finance institution Soro Yiriwaso, with which she is on her first individual loan.

With this loan, she intends to make trips to Lomé (capital of the Republic of Togo) to buy embroidered fabrics. She makes her sales at the grand marketplace of Koutiala to essentially women customers. Sales are made at the retail level, in bulk, cash accepted or credit, payable monthly. She intends to realize a profit of 70,000 francs CFA per month that she envisions using to cover the loan interest with Soro Yiriwaso and to cope with the expenses of her two children. With her prospects, she envisions opening a shop to sell fabrics at the Koutiala marketplace.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy fabrics (embroidered)

loans.name: Khursand

texts.en:
Khursand is a hard-working entrepreneur from Dushanbe, Tajikistan. He is married and the happy father of six children. He owns a market vending business where he sells clothing for men at a busy locale. Khursand decided to start his own business after he was unable to find other work. Now, two years later, he has about $2000 invested in inventory and he makes about $300 a month profit. In addition to his business, Khursand also works part time as a taxi driver, which enables him to earn more income.

Khursand has requested a loan of 2500 Somoni (US$750) that he will repay within nine months. He will purchase new inventory for his business. Khursand will use the profits from his business to improve his standard of living and do some remodeling of his home.

loans.use: Purchasing the new goods for selling.

loans.name: Bakhtiyor

texts.en:
S. Bakhtiyor is 32 years old. He is married and the father of three wonderful children. In 2002, Bakhtiyor was unemployed. One of his friends invited him to start a business repairing and making furniture. This was something new for him, but he decided to try. Fortunately everything went well and the customers were convinced about the quality of the products.

Bakhtiyor's portfolio of clients is increasing and he feels so proud of his achievements. Since Bakhtiyor has a lot of clients, the business is very successful and brings stable and significant income allowing him to improve the living conditions of his family.

Today Bakhtiyor requests 1700 Somoni (US$500) for purchasing wood and supplies for making furniture. He would like to thank everyone supporting him and promises to repay the loan within nine months. Bakhtiyor is counting on your help. Be an important part of the growth of Bakhtiyor’s business.

loans.use: To purchase wood and supplies for making furniture.

loans.name: Davlatsho

texts.en:
Davlatsho is married with two children. He’s a businessman from Dushanbe where he sells men’s jeans, pullovers and shirts in the city market. Davlatsho is very enterprising, has vast experience working as a vendor and is full of creative ideas. A reasonable pricing policy and client-friendly service have always been priorities in his work and have helped to ensure the success of his business, which he has been running for five years. Currently, he has about $6,000 invested in the business and his monthly income is about $300-400.

Davlatsho is requesting a loan of 2500 Somoni (US$750) to increase his inventory. He promises to repay the loan within nine months. He believes that having this additional turnover capital will help him minimize his sales risk and provide stable financial support for his family. Moreover, it will help him get closer to his ultimate goal of purchasing a big store of his own one day.

loans.use: To increase his inventory.

loans.name: Zlata

texts.en:
Zlata was born in 1960 and she lives in a suburb of Gracanica, Bosnia.  She lives with her husband and their adult son, who is employed.  Zlata works as a cleaning lady at the local elementary school, earning about 700KM/month (the equivalent of roughly $470 USD.)  To support her family, she also grows vegetables and sells them in the local marketplace.  

Zlata requests a loan of 300KM from Women for Women, International. She will use this loan to purchase minerals and to prepare her field for planting vegetables such as carrots, onions, tomatoes and corn.  This is Zlata`s third microfinance loan; she used the previous loans for agricultural purposes also, and she repaid them successfully.

loans.use: To purchase farming supplies

loans.name: Zora

texts.en:
Zora was born in 1950. She is married and lives with her husband and their two adult sons in Kalenderovci, a village in Bosnia.  Zora supports her family by growing vegetables and by selling the milk from her cow in the local marketplace. Her husband is retired, but helps her with the farm work.

Zora request a loan of 1,200KM from Women for Women, International. She will use the loan to buy a second cow. The additional income she will earn from selling the cow`s milk and milk products will help to improve the quality of life for her family.

loans.use: To buy a cow.

loans.name: Nguyen Thi

texts.vi: Chị Là năm nay 33 tuổi. Năm  2005 chị tham gia vào Quỹ tình thương và vay 3.000.000đ để đầu tư vốn cho chồng làm xưởng mộc và cho thu nhập 1.500.000đ / tháng. Đến nay qua 3 năm tham gia Quỹ, nhờ biết cách làm ăn xưởng mộc của gia đình chị phát triển rất thuận lợi và cho thu nhập 3.500.000đ/ tháng. Vòng vốn tới chị xin vay 15.000.000đ để tiếp tục đầu tư vốn mua gỗ phục vụ cho công việc sản xuất của gia đình
texts.en:
Mrs. L. is 33 years old. She joined TYM Fund in 2005, and borrowed 3.000.000 VND in the first round of loan to open a small carpentry workshop for her husband, helping the family earn 1.500.000 VND per month. Now after three years, her family’s workshop has become much more popular and organized, which helps generate 3.500.000 VND monthly. In the next round of loan, Mrs. L. would like to borrow 15.000.000 VND ($900) to purchase more wood for the workshop.

Translated from Vietnamese by Khoa Nguyen, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: By wood

loans.name: Binh

texts.vi: Chị Bình năm nay 53 tuổi, là thành viên của Quỹ tình thương từ năm 1998. Sau khi tham gia vào quỹ do gia đình có điều kiện thuận lợi gần chợ trung tâm của huyện nên chị mạnh dạn vay vốn về đầu tư vào buôn bán các mặt hàng tạp hoá. Hiện tại ngoài thu nhập từ buôn bán hàng tháng gia đình chị còn có thêm nguồn thu nhập ổn định từ lương của  chồng và sự hỗ trợ của các con đi lao động xuất khẩu nên kinh tế gia đình chị ngày càng phát triển. Với mức thu nhập 6.500.000đ/ tháng  không chỉ hoàn trả vốn vay và chi tiêu gia đình chị còn tiết kiệm và mua sắm được nhiều trang thiết bị phục vụ cho cuộc sống hàng ngày. Vòng vốn tới chị dự định vay 15.000.000đ  để lấy thêm các mặt hàng đồ nhựa và các đồ gia dụng khác phục vụ nhu cầu của bà con  trong dịp Tết
texts.en:
Ms Binh is 53 years old, and has been a member of TYM fund since 1998. She joined the fund with the condition of doing business near the market at the center of the district. Therefore, she borrowed a loan to invest in a grocery store. Currently, in addition to the monthly income from her store, her family has additional source of income from her husband's job and assistance from her children who are also working, and thus their economic situation improves steadily. With average income of 390 USD per month, and after repaying the loans and taking care of their needs, her family is still abL. to save and buy other things to attend to their daily lives. For this loan, she wishes to borrow 900 USD to purchase additional household appliances and utensils for her store to meet the demand of the customers for the upcoming Tet Holiday.

Translated from Vietnamese by Thu Ostrander, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Invest in her grocery

loans.name: Thuy

texts.vi: Chị Trương Thị Thuý là thành viên của Quỹ tình thương từ năm 2000. Trước khi tham gia vào quỹ kinh tế gia đình còn nhiều khó khăn, thu nhập của gia đình chủ yếu trông vào  việc đi thu mua phế liệu. Do thiếu vốn nên thu nhập từ thu mua phế liệu chỉ đạt  khoảng 20.000đồng /ngày . Từ khi tham gia vào quỹ nhờ có thêm vốn nên công việc thu mua phế liệu mang lại thu nhập cao hơn nhờ đó kinh tế gia đình chị dần nâng lên. Đến  nay chị đã mua được máy xay sát gạo về để xay sát cho nhân trong xã. Thu nhập hiện nay của gia đình đã đạt 3 triệuđồng/tháng. Vòng vốn tới chị mong muốn được vay 7.000.000đ để đầu tư vốn mua thêm máy sát gạo.
texts.en:
Ms. T. Thi Thuy has been a member of TYM fund since 2000. Before joining the fund, her family's economic situation was difficult with their main source of income from buying & selling scraps. Due to lack of capital, they were only able to bring in about 1.5 USD per day from this work. Since joining the fund, they were able to borrow additional money to invest in the business, and thus their income has been steadily rising. She was able to purchase a rice grinding machine to mill rice for the local community. Their income now averages 180 USD per month. For this loan, she wishes to borrow 425 USD to buy additional rice grinding machine.

Translated from Vietnamese by Thu Ostrander, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: business

loans.name: Tifa

texts.en:
A Kiva Fellow recently interviewed Tifa`s mother-in-law. To see a clip from the interview, check out the YouTube video at: http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=fvo6j84FKZ8. Tifa`s children are in the clip!

Tifa was born in 1982. She lives in Srebrenica, a village devastated by the Bosnian war in 1995.  In 1995, she was deported to Tuzla, where she lived until 2001 before returning to Srebrenica.  She is married, has two young daughters, and is studying law at a local university.  

To help support her family, Tifa requests a loan of 600KM from Women for Women, International, which she will use to invest in an agricultural project with her mother-in-law. Together, they will purchase the seeds and materials needed to grow and prepare a special corn-based product. The product is a mix of corn and grasses, and can be stored to feed cattle in the winter time. This is considered a specialty food for cattle, and is in high demand in Srebrenica. The corn and grasses will largely be grown and prepared by her mother-in-law, because Tifa is busy studying and taking care of her children.

Tifa’s loan will be guaranteed by her mother-in-law, Muška Efendic.

loans.use: To buy farming supplies

loans.name: Hien

texts.vi: Chị Hiến năm nay 42 tuổi, chị tham gia Quỹ tình thương từ năm 2007. Gia đình chị hiện có nghề làm bánh cuốn truyền thống nên với mức vốn vay qua các vòng chị đều đầu tư vào mua nguyên liệu phục vụ cho công việc sản xuất bánh cuốn của gi đình. Hiện nay với mức thu nhập 3.000.000đ/ tháng đây cũng là công việc đem lại nguồn thu nhập chính cho gia đình chị .Vòng vốn tới chị xin vay 9 triệu đồng để đầu tư mua 2 tấn lúa dự trữ để làm bánh cuốn
texts.en:
Ms. Hien is 42 years old, and joined TYM fund in 2007. Her family has a traditional profession of making rice crepes, and so she has been investing her prior loans in buying supplies for their business of crepes production. Presently, with income of 183 USD per month, this business is their family's main source of income. For this loan, she wishes to borrow 550 USD to buy 2 tons of rice to reserve for making crepes

Translated from Vietnamese by Thu Ostrander, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Business

loans.name: Pham Thi

texts.vi: Chị Hiến năm nay 42 tuổi, chị tham gia Quỹ tình thương từ năm 2007. Gia đình chị hiện có nghề làm bánh cuốn truyền thống nên với mức vốn vay qua các vòng chị đều đầu tư vào mua nguyên liệu phục vụ cho công việc sản xuất bánh cuốn của gia đình. Hiện nay với mức thu nhập 3.000.000đ/ tháng đây cũng là công việc đem lại nguồn thu nhập chính cho gia đình chị .Vòng vốn tới chị xin vay 9 triệu đồng để đầu tư mua 2 tấn lúa dự trữ để làm bánh cuốn
texts.en:
Ms. H. is 42 years old, and joined TYM fund in 2007. Her family has a traditional profession of making rice crepes, and so she has been investing her prior loans in buying supplies for their business of crepes production. Presently, with income of 183 USD per month, this business is their family's main source of income. For this loan, she wishes to borrow 550 USD to buy 2 tons of rice to reserve for making crepes

Translated from Vietnamese by Thu Ostrander, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Business

loans.name: Hue

texts.vi: Chị Huệ năm nay 28 tuổi và mới tham gia Quỹ tình hương được hơn 1 năm. Gia đình chị sống ở gần chợ nên rất thuận tiện cho việc kinh doanh và buôn bán.  Trong những năm qua ngoài làm ruộng vợ chồng chị còn buôn th Năm 2007 chị được vay vốn từ quỹ đã giúp cho gia đình chị có vốn đầu tư vào buôn thêm các mặt hàng tạp hoá.  Trước kia thu nhập của anh chị từ buôn bán chỉ đạt 1,2 triệu đồng/ tháng. Đến nay mức thu nhập đã tăng lên 2.000.000đ/ tháng. Vòngvốn tới chị mong muốn được vay 9 triệu đồng để đầu tư thêm vốn vào kinh doanh hàng tạp hoá
texts.en:
Ms. Hue is 28 years old and joined TYM fund over a year ago. Her family resides near the market, so it is very convenient for retail business. In addition to rice farming, she and her husband also has a grocery store. In 2007, she was able to borrow from the fund and invested in their grocery store by buying additional products to sell. Before joining the fund, their income was only about 73 USD per month. Now their income has risen to 122 USD per month. For this next loan, she wishes to borrow 550 USD to invest in her grocery store

Translated from Vietnamese by Thu Ostrander, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Business

loans.name: Huong

texts.vi: Chị Hương năm nay 37 tuổi, chị đang sống cùng chồng và hai con tại huyện Ý Yên tỉnh nam Định. Gia đình chị có nghề buôn bán than hoa và chè xanh. Hàng  tuần chồng chị đi vào tỉnh Hoà Bình lấy than hoa và chè xanh về để chị bán cho các hộ bán lẻ trong huyện. Hiện tại đây cũng là công việc đem lại nguồn thu nhập  chính cho gia đình chị . Từ chỗ gia đình luôn thiếu vốn để buôn bán đến nay công việc kinh doanh của gia đình chị đã ngày càng phát triển và cho thu nhập ổn định 2.000.000đ/ tháng. Vòng vốn tới chị mong muốn được vay 9 triệu đồng để đầu tư thêm vốn vào kinh doanh than hoa và chè xanh.
texts.en:
Ms. Huong is 37 yrs old . She lives with her husband and 2 children in the District of Y Ten in the town of Nam Dinh. Her family has a business selling charcoal, flowers and fresh tea leaves. Her husband goes into Nam Dinh every week to buy wholesale the charcoal, flowers and tea ,and brings them home for her to sell retail to the people in her local district. This is their family's main source of income. They went from always lacking money to purchase items for the business to expanding their business, bringing in 120.00 USD per month. For her next loan she wishes to borrow 550 USD to invest in her business.

Translated from Vietnamese by Thu Ostrander, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Business

loans.name: Lan

texts.vi: Chị Ngô Thị Lan năm nay 52 tuổi, gia đình chị có 3 con đèu đã trưởng thành. Hiện nay chị Lan đang bán hàng ăn sáng tại chợ còn chồng chị cho thuê bàn ghế phục vụ đám cưới. Với tổng thu nhập đạt 2.000.000đ/ tháng cuộc sống của hai vợ chồng chị khá ổn định. Vòngvốn tới chị mong muốn được vay 9 triệu dồng, một phần chị đầu tư thêm vốn vào mua thêm thực phẩm phục vụ việc kinh doanh hàng ăn sáng, phần còn lại chị đầu tư mua thêm bàn ghế phụcvụ cho công việc kinh doanh của chồng.
texts.en:
Ms. N. Thi Lan is 52 yrs old and has 3 grown children. Currently she sells breakfast food at the market, while her husband rents furniture for wedding parties. With a combined income of 122 USD per month, their family life is stable. For her next loan, she wishes to borrow 550 USD with 1/4 of the loan to purchase additional food items to serve in her restaurant, and the remainder of the loan to buy more chairs and tables to use in her husband's business.

Translated from Vietnamese by Thu Ostrander, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Business

loans.name: Phuong

texts.vi: Chị Phượng tham gia Quỹ tình thương từ năm 2007. Tuy mới 19 tuổi nhưng chịPhượng đã có khá nhiều kinh nghiệm trong kinh doanh hoa quả. Hiện nay với sự giúp đỡ của chồng và nguồn vốn vay của Quỹ tình thương công việc kinh doanh hoa quả của gia đình chị đã cho thu nhập 2 triệu đồng/ tháng. N.ài kinh doanh buôn bán gia đình chị còn có thêm nguồn thu từ chăn nuôi nên  dù mới xay dựng gia đình nhưng kinh tếcủa vợ chồng chị Phượng khá ổn định. Vòng vốn tới chị mong muốn được vay 9 triệu đồng để đầu tư thêm vốn vào công việc kinh doanh hoa quả
texts.en:
Ms. Phuong joined TYM fund since 2007. Even though she is only 19 yrs old, she already has a lot of experience in selling fruits. Currently with the help of her husband and a loan from TYM fund, her fruit selling business brings in 122 USD per month. In addition to her fruit business, another source of her income is from raising animals. Therefore, even though recently married, her family's income situation is quite stable. For this loan, she wishes to borrow 550 USD to invest in her fruit selling business

Translated from Vietnamese by Thu Ostrander, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Business

loans.name: Lan

texts.vi: Chị Dương Thị Lan năm nay 46 tuổi. Trước khi tham gia vào quỹ chị Lan đi buôn bán phế liệu còn chồng chị đi đúc thuê thu nhập gia đình không ổn định đời sống khó khăn . Năm 2006 chị tham gia Quỹ tình thương và vay vốn để gia đình đầu tư mở xưởng đúc tại nhà.  Đến nay gia đình có xưởng đúc đồng  với 3 Công nhân  cho thu nhập ổn định 3 triệu đồng/ tháng. Vòng vốn tới chị xin vay 9 triệu đồng để đầu tư mua nguyên liệu phục vụ cho xưởng đúc đồng của gia đình.
texts.en:
Ms. Doung Thi Lan is 46 yrs old. Before joining the fund, she sold scraps while her husband worked as a moulder; the family's income was not stable and they had a difficult life. In 2006, she joined the fund and borrowed money to open a metal casting factory at her home. Now her business has 3 employees and brings in 180 USD per month. For this next loan, she wishes to borrow 550 USD to purchase raw materials for her family's business.

Translated from Vietnamese by Thu Ostrander, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Business

loans.name: Adilia

texts.es: Adilia tiene 28 años de edad, vive junto a su pareja que es mecánico y sus 2 hijos que estudian y son sus motivos de seguir adelante. Se dedica a la venta de comida por las noches (salchipapas: papas fritas con salchichas), este trabajo lo viene realizando desde hace 4 años atrás. Lo que le gusta de su trabajo es preparar bien su comida para que sus clientes se sientan satisfechos de su buena sazón y también le gusta entablar conversación con todos. Este negocio le es muy rentable, ya que es una cosa fácil de hacer y sobre todo es bien practico. Le va bien en este trabajo por lo que no muestra dificultad alguna.  Este es el primer préstamo que solicita con MFP. Con el dinero mandar a construir una ramada (techo a base de ramas que cubre un espacio exterior determinado) y así vender tranquilamente, ya que actualmente vende dentro de su casa.
texts.en:
Adilia is 28 years old and lives with her partner, a mechanic, and her two children who are in school and are her motivation to forge ahead. She dedicates herself to selling food at night (salchipapas: french fries with sausage), work which she has been doing for four years now. What she likes about her job is making good food so that her customers enjoy her cooking, and also spending time chatting with them while they eat. This business is very profitable, since the food is easy to prepare and – most of all -- very practical. She is doing well in this endeavor as it doesn’t present any difficulties for her. This is the first loan she requests with MFP. With the funds, she will order a ramada (a roof made out of branches that covers a specified outdoor space) built so she can conduct her sales peacefully since she currently transacts her business from within her home.


Translated from Spanish by Mary Lynn Malaby, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Outfit a space outside of her home where she can conduct her food sales.

loans.name: Hoa

texts.vi: Là thành viên của Quỹ tình thương từ năm 2000, đến nay qua 8 năm tham gia Quỹ chị Hoa đã sử dụng vốn rất hiệu quả trong việc buôn bán phế liệu. Ban đầu chị chỉ đi thu mua phế liệu lẻ đến nay do đã có nhiều kinh nghiệm nguồn vốn ngày càng được bổ xung nhiều hơn nên chị đã chuyển sang thu mau phế liêu tại nhà và cung cấp cho các xưởng đúc tại địa phương. Công việc này đem lại cho gia đình chị mức thu nhập 3 triệu đồng/ tháng. Vòng vốn tới chị mong muốn được vay 10 triệu đồng đầu tư thêm vốn cho việc thu mua phế liệu của gia đình
texts.en:
A member of the fund since 2000, and for the past 8 years since joining the fund, Ms. Hoa has utilize the loans very effectively in her business selling scrap metal. At the beginning, she bought and sold the scraps retail. Now with more experience and additional money to invest, she switched to a business at her home and supplying scrap metals to local metal-casting factories. This business brings her family 180 USD per month. For this next loan, she wishes to borrow 600 USD to invest in her scrap metal business.

Translated from Vietnamese by Thu Ostrander, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Business

loans.name: Katerine

texts.es: Katerine tiene 28 años, es madre de 3 hijos, vive junto a su esposo, quien la ayuda en lo posible y necesario.  Ella es propietaria de un motocarro, que es manejado un chofer particular, brinda servicio de transporte de pasajeros desde hace un año. Se siente contenta porque su vehículo está bien cuidado, porque la persona que trabaja con ella es muy responsable y hacendoso. Este negocio le es muy rentable, ya que recibe ganancias diariamente. Esta muy satisfecha, le va muy bien. Es la primera vez que solicita un préstamo con MFP. El dinero que solicita será utilizado en reparar algunas fallas de su motocarro, para que trabaje al 100% y ella se sienta tranquila y segura.
texts.en:
Katerine is 28 years old and the mother of three children. She lives with her husband who helps her whenever needed and whenever possible. She is the owner of a motorcycle rickshaw, which she drives as a private chauffeur, and has been providing passenger transportation services for the past year. She is happy because her vehicle is well-cared for, and because her co-worker is very responsible and hardworking. This business is very profitable, as she receives daily earnings. She is very satisfied, things are going very well. This is the first time she is requesting a loan with MFP. The money requested will be used to do some repairs on the van so that it can work 100% and she can feel comfortable and secure.

Translated from Spanish by Emily Martyn, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Motorcycle rickshaw repairs

loans.name: Maria

texts.es: Maria es madre soltera, tiene 39 años de edad y dos hijos, siendo uno de ellos ya independiente, quedando a su cargo su pequeña de 9 años. Se dedica a brindar servicios de bufete (comida para eventos), trabaja por horas y hace concesiones con algunas instituciones, este trabajo lo realiza desde hace 9 años. Lo que le gusta es que se relaciona con mucha gente, quienes degustan de sus distintos platos. Le es muy rentable, ya que tiene una clientela selecta a quienes les gusta mucho su comida y recomiendan sus bocadillos. Le va excelente. Esta es la primera vez que solicita un préstamo con MFP. Con el dinero solicitado comprará más utensilios de cocina, como ollas a presión y platos.
texts.en:
Maria is a 39-year-old single mother of two children. As one is already self-reliant, the youngest, the nine year old, is left in her care. Maria provides a catering service for events, which she has done for nine years. She works part time and has made agreements with some institutions. She enjoys getting to know many people, and having them taste her different dishes. Her business is very profitable as she has a select group of clientele who really appreciate her food and recommend her sandwiches. Things are going extremely well. This is the first time she has asked for a loan from MFP. With the money she receives, she will buy more cookware, such as pressure cookers and dishes.

Translated from Spanish by Emily Martyn, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of cookware to improve her business

loans.name: Do Thi

texts.vi: Chị đình Chị Hương năm nay 41 tuổi, chị tham gia Quỹ tình thương từ năm 2000. Gia đình chị vốn có nghề ánh gaiàm bQuỹ chị Hương cũng vay thêm vốn để đầu tư mua nguyên liệu sản xuất bánh gai. Qua các năm vay vốn của quỹ đã giúp cho gia đình chị mở rộng sản xuất kinh doanh. Hiện nay không chỉ sản xuất banh gai gia đình chị còn đầu tư  mua máy tuốt lúa để chồng làm mỗi vụ cho thu nhập 4 đến 6 triệu đông . Vòng vốn tới chị mong muốn được vay 11 triệu đồng để đầu tư mua thêm một chiếc máy tuốt lúa mới phục vụ bà con phát triển kinh tế gia đình
texts.en:
Mrs. Hương is 41 years old. She joined the Fund in 2000. At the beginning, her family originally made a living from selling "bánh gai", a typical Vietnamese dessert. She was borrowing to buy more ingredients to produce the desserts. Those loans helped her family to expand their production. Besides that, the family has now invested into the purchase of a plucking machine that the husband can use every season for an income of 4-6 million dong. For the next round, she would like to borrow 11 million dong to buy an additional, new plucking machine to serve others and improve further the family's revenues.

Translated from Vietnamese by Minh Bui, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Business

loans.name: Mayre

texts.es: Mayre tiene 27 años, es soltera, tiene una hija de 5 años que estudia, vive independientemente en una parte de la casa de sus padres. Se dedica a la venta de comida, ya que brinda pensión a un grupo de trabajadores de una institución que se encuentra muy cerca de su casa. Esta actividad la viene realizando desde hace 7 años en su propia casa. Lo que le gusta de su trabajo es que se siente activa en todo momento, y sobre todo dar una buena atención a sus clientes es lo primordial. Le es rentable su trabajo porque mantiene a los clientes que tuvo desde sus inicios y obtiene nuevos. Le va muy bien y no tiene queja alguna. Es la primera vez que solicita un préstamo con MFP. Con este dinero quiere comprar mesas y sillas para dar una mejor acogida a sus clientes.
texts.en:
Mayre is 27 years old, she is single and has a 5 year old daughter who is studying. She lives independently in her parents’ house. She works selling food that she supplies to an institution near by. She has been selling food for the past 7 years from her home. She likes her work because she is active all the time, providing good service to her clients is a priority for her.
