They are then washed, ironed and sold in bulk by wholesalers in Tanzania to retailers who re-wash and re-iron them for sale on the streets and in the surrounding towns and villages. These clothes are becoming increasingly popular, especially amongst the younger generation, because of their low cost and the general appeal of anything modern.

Mariamu works at her business for 9-12 hours per day, 6 days per week. She currently earns about 100 USD a month from her business. She is requesting a loan of $400 in order to purchase additional used clothing for resale. Mariamu thanks you for supporting her business!

ABOUT SELFINA:
SELFINA has taken a lead role as a pioneer of micro-credit in Tanzania through Micro-Leasing. The organization is engaged in the economic empowerment of women in Tanzania through the provision of a leasing and leaseback microfinance facility. Customs and traditions in Tanzania make it difficult for women to own land and assets, so they are termed non-creditworthy by financial institutions. This leads to poor financial support and poor access to basic needs and services for women with low incomes. One of the primary advantages of microleasing is that it allows clients to use their equipment as collateral for future loans with SELFINA, thus enabling them to borrow larger sums in the future.

loans.use: To purchase additional used clothing for resale

loans.name: Ayoko

texts.fr: Mariée et mère de 3 enfants à charge, Madame K. Ayoko est née à Aklakou en 1958. Depuis plus de 20 ans, elle y exerce le commerce d’alimentation générale et la vente de bouillie comme activité secondaire, à ciel ouvert, grâce auquel elle subvient aux multiples besoins de sa famille. En temps de pluie et de fort ensoleillement, son activité tourne au ralenti dans la mesure où elle ne l’exerce pas sous un abri devant protéger aussi bien les marchandises, ses clients qu’elle-même. Dans le souci de mieux rentabiliser son affaire, elle se propose de réaménager une boutique qu’elle a déjà construite. Mais elle ne dispose plus suffisamment de fonds. C’est pourquoi elle sollicite un crédit pour réaliser son projet.
texts.en:
Married and the mother of 3 children for whom she is responsible, Mrs. Ayko K. was born in Aklakou in 1958. For more than 20 years, she has been tending a little grocery store and selling porridge as a secondary activity, out in the open. Her two businesses bring in enough to cover the many needs of her family.

When it is rainy or the sun is too hot, her business slows down since she has no roof to protect her, her customers, and her merchandise from the elements. Wishing to make her business more profitable, she would like to furnish a little store that she has already built. However, she does not have enough money to do this. For that reason, she is requesting a loan to help her make her plans come true.

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: furnishing a little grocery store

loans.name: Elizabeth

texts.en:
Mambo from Tanzania! This is 28-year-old Elizabeth G. from Mwanza, a beautiful city on the shores of Lake Victoria. (Lake Victoria is famous not only for being one of the largest lakes in the world, but also because it feeds the Nile River, a very important source of life for Africa.)

Elizabeth is married and has one child who is 3 years old. She has been running a maize business since 2005. She works at the business for 9-12 hours per day and is assisted by her husband. Elizabeth currently earns about US$10 a month from her business. She is requesting a loan of $400 in order to purchase maize in bulk. Elizabeth thanks you for your support!

ABOUT SELFINA: SELFINA has taken a lead role as a pioneer of micro-credit in Tanzania through Micro-Leasing. The organization is engaged in the economic empowerment of women in Tanzania through the provision of a leasing and leaseback microfinance facility. Customs and traditions in Tanzania make it difficult for women to own land and assets, so they are termed non-creditworthy by financial institutions. This leads to poor financial support and poor access to basic needs and services for women with low incomes. One of the primary advantages of microleasing is that it allows clients to use their equipment as collateral for future loans with SELFINA, thus enabling them to borrow larger sums in the future.

loans.use: To purchase maize in bulk

loans.name: Tsotsovi

texts.fr: Agée de 65 ans, Madame A. Tsotsovi est une veuve ayant 4 personnes à charge aux besoins desquelles elle subvient grâce à la commercialisation de céréales. Actuellement, sa clientèle a presque triplé mais son faible pouvoir d’achat ne lui permet pas de les satisfaire. Cette situation crée un certain mécontentement au niveau des clients fidèles. C’est dans la perspective d’augmenter son pouvoir d’achat aux fins de mieux satisfaire les clients et d’augmenter ainsi son chiffre d’affaire pour offrir de meilleures conditions d’existence à son ménage qu’elle sollicite un crédit. Ce crédit lui servira aussi de fonds de roulement.
texts.en:
Aged 65, Mrs. Tsotsovi A. is a widow with four people to look after. She provides for their needs by selling cereals. Her clientele has now almost tripled but her weak purchasing power does not allow her to meet their requirements. This situation is making her loyal customers rather unhappy. She is therefore requesting a loan so that she can increase her buying power and better satisfy her customers as well as increase her revenue and thus improve the living conditions of her household. The loan will also serve as working capital.

Translated from French by Sarah Llewellyn, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Supplies and sale of cereals

loans.name: Akou

texts.fr: Akou A. est une commerçante des articles de fête à Atakpamé, une ville située à environ 170 kilomètres de Lomé, la capitale togolaise. Agé de 39 ans, elle est mariée et mère de 4 enfants. Elle désire avec ce crédit augmenter la capacité de son commerce. Ceci lui peremttra de  gagner plus d’argent afin de subvenir aux besoins de ses enfants.
texts.en:
Akou A. is a merchant of holiday items in Atakpamé, a city located about 170 km from Lomé, the Togolese capital. She is 39 years old, married, and the mother of four. She would like to use this loan to increase her business capacity. This will enable her to earn more money in order to provide for her children.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy goods for resale

loans.name: Zubeda

texts.en:
Mambo (greetings!) from Tanzania! This is 23-year-old Zubeda Harufani from Mwanza, a beautiful city on the shores of Lake Victoria. (Lake Victoria is famous not only for being one of the largest lakes in the world but also because it feeds the Nile River, a very important source of life for Africa.)

Zubeda is married, with one child who is 3 years old. Zubeda has been running a plastic business since 2005. She purchases rolls of clear plastic, cuts the plastic, and seals one end to make bags that closely resemble the bags you receive when you purchase a fish from the fish store. She then bundles several bags together and sells them to vendors of all sorts, who may pile tiny mangos or figs into the bags to sell to people who pass by foot, car, or daladala (mini city buses).

Zubeda is requesting a loan of $400 in order to purchase additional plastic material and a machine that cuts the plastic. Zubeda thanks you for supporting her!

ABOUT SELFINA:
SELFINA has taken a lead role as a pioneer of micro-credit in Tanzania through Micro-Leasing. The organization is engaged in the economic empowerment of women in Tanzania through the provision of a leasing and leaseback micro finance facility. Customs and traditions in Tanzania make it difficult for women to own land and assets, so they are termed non-creditworthy by financial institutions. This leads to poor financial support and poor access to basic needs and services for women with low incomes. One of the primary advantages of micro leasing is that it allows clients to use their equipment as collateral for future loans with SELFINA, thus enabling them to borrow larger sums in the future.

loans.use: To purchase plastic material to make bags and a machine that cuts the plastic

loans.name: Degninou

texts.fr: Degninou F. est âgé de 42 ans, marié et père de 3 enfants tous à l’école. Il exerce l’activité de la couture et est compté parmi les meilleurs de son secteur à Atakpamé, une ville située au centre du Togo. Pour donner plus de teneur à son activité, Degninou souhaite avec ce crédit acheter une nouvelle machine et aussi des tissus pour la commercialisation
texts.en:
Degninou F. is 42 years old, married and the father of three children, all of whom are at school. He works as a tailor and is considered one of the best in the business in Atakpamé, a town in central Togo. To bolster his business Deginou wants to use this loan to buy a new sewing machine as well as fabrics that he can sell.

Translated from French by Sarah Llewellyn, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy a sewing machine and fabric to sell

loans.name: Reyhan

texts.en:
Reyhan lives in Khachmaz. She was born in 1986. She is married but does not have any children. 

Reyhan's husband has been in the taxi business for one year. 

Now they are requesting a loan of 970 AZN to buy the spare parts to the taxi. 

Reyhan's husband is pictured in the photo.

loans.use: To buy the spare parts

loans.name: Maida

texts.en:
Mambo from Tanzania! This is 34-year-old Maida M. from Mwanza. She is married with two children, ages five and 14. Maida has been running a household products stand since 2006. Vendors that sell household products in Tanzania either sell them on a blanket on the street or in a store. The items they sell vary from ladles to dishwashing racks to soap. She works at the business for nine hours per day, six days per week and is assisted by her husband. Maida currently earns about 150 USD from her business. She is requesting a loan of 325 USD in order to buy more stock in bulk in order to resell them. Maida thanks you for your support!

SELFINA has taken a lead role as a pioneer of microcredit in Tanzania. The organization is devoted to the economic empowerment of women in Tanzania through microfinance as a practical way to achieve the economic and social emancipation of women. Customs and traditions in Tanzania make it difficult for women to own land and assets; thus, they are deemed non-creditworthy by financial institutions. This leads to poor financial support and hence poor access to basic needs and services for women with low incomes. One of the primary advantages of microleasing is that it allows clients to use the equipment as collateral for future loans with SELFINA, enabling them to borrow larger sums in the future.

loans.use: To buy more stock of household items in bulk

loans.name: Salimatou

texts.fr: Salimatou A. est revendeuse des objets en céramique à Atakpamé, une ville située au centre du Togo. Cette activité étant sa principale source de revenu, elle souhaite accroître sa capacité par le crédit qu’elle va bénéficier afin de faire plus de profits pour la survie de sa famille
texts.en:
Salimatou A. retails ceramic objects in Atakpamé, a city in the centre of Togo. This activity being her main source of income, she wishes to increase her sales capacity with the loan in order to make greater profits for the survival of her family.

Translated from French by Laure Kwon, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy merchandise for resale

loans.name: Hadasa

texts.en:
Mambo from Tanzania! This is 33-year-old Hadasa M. from Mwanza. She is widowed with three children between the ages of three and 10 years old. Additionally, she is responsible for supporting one dependent because he is an orphan. Hadasa has been running a maize business since 2005. A typical maize business is a stand on the side of the road where maize is often piled high in baskets. Customers can scrutinize the quality of the product before purchase and specify the exact amount they would like to purchase. Hadasa works at the business for 12 hours per day, five days per week and is assisted by her brother. Hadasa currently earns about 250 USD from her business. She is requesting a loan of 450 USD in order to buy more stock of maize. Hadasa thanks you for your support!

SELFINA has taken a lead role as a pioneer of microcredit in Tanzania. The organization is devoted to the economic empowerment of women in Tanzania through microfinance as a practical way to achieve the economic and social emancipation of women. Customs and traditions in Tanzania make it difficult for women to own land and assets; thus, they are deemed non-creditworthy by financial institutions. This leads to poor financial support and hence poor access to basic needs and services for women with low incomes. One of the primary advantages of microleasing is that it allows clients to use the equipment as collateral for future loans with SELFINA, enabling them to borrow larger sums in the future.

loans.use: To buy more stock of maize

loans.name: Victorine

texts.fr: Victorine K. est une revendeuse de poissons au grand marché d’Atakpamé, une ville située à environ 170 kilomètres de Lomé, la capitale togolaise. Passionnée par son activité et voulant la promouvoir, Victorine espère avec ce crédit augmenter ses achats en cherchant d’autres fournisseurs afin de réduire les prix d’achat et par conséquent une augmentation des marges bénéficiaires.
texts.en:
Victorine K. sells fish in the main market of Atakpamé, a city approximately 170 kilometres from Lomé, the capital of Togo. Passionate about her business, and wishing to promote it, Victorine hopes that with this loan she will be able to increase her volumes by finding new suppliers with lower prices, thereby increasing her profit margin.

Translated from French by Laure Kwon, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy fish for resale

loans.name: Magdalena

texts.en:
Mambo from Tanzania! This is 35-year-old Magdalena M. from Mwanza. She is married with four children between the ages of eight and 18 years. Magdalena has been running an African clothes business since 2006. She sells traditional clothing worn by Tanzanian women, called kanga and vitenge. The kanga is a piece of printed cotton fabric often with a border along all four sides. It is printed using the silkscreen method with its pattern in frames. Kitenge (the Swahili plural is vitenge) is a cotton fabric with wax print, printed by using rotary printing machines. Kitenge is an expressive textile: the various colors, patterns, writings and symbols represent moods, feelings, cultures, and traditions of native African people. Magdalena works at the business for 12 hours per day, six days per week. Magdalena currently earns about 120 USD from her business. She is requesting a loan of 400 USD in order to purchase more African clothes to resell. Magdalena thanks you for your support!

SELFINA has taken a lead role as a pioneer of microcredit in Tanzania. The organization is devoted to the economic empowerment of women in Tanzania through microfinance as a practical way to achieve the economic and social emancipation of women. Customs and traditions in Tanzania make it difficult for women to own land and assets; thus, they are deemed non-creditworthy by financial institutions. This leads to poor financial support and hence poor access to basic needs and services for women with low incomes. One of the primary advantages of microleasing is that it allows clients to use the equipment as collateral for future loans with SELFINA, enabling them to borrow larger sums in the future.

loans.use: To purchase more clothing for resale

loans.name: Kafui

texts.fr: Kafui B. est âgée de 38 ans, mariée et mère de 3 enfants. Elle est revendeuse de pagnes depuis 4 ans à Atakpamé, une ville située à environ 170 kilomètres de Lomé, la capitale du Togo. Pour répondre aux exigences de sa clientèle, Kafui désire avec ce crédit approvisionner sa boutique. Elle compte sur cette opportunité pour améliorer les conditions de vie de sa famille.
texts.en:
Kafui B. is 38 years old, married, and the mother of 3 children. She's been a pagnes (colorful African cloth) reseller for 4 years in Atakpamé, a city located approximately 170 kilometers from Lomé, the capital of Togo. To meet customer demand, Kafui wishes to use this loan to resupply her shop. She counts on this opportunity to improve the living conditions of her family.

Translated from French by Patrick Stadelmann, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy and resell pagnes (colorful African cloth)

loans.name: Ndeshi

texts.en:
Mambo from Tanzania! This is 32-year-old Ndeshi M. from Mwanza. She is married with two children, ages three and nine. Ndeshi has been running a clothing business since 2008. She works at her business for 12 hours a day, six days a week. Ndeshi currently earns about 150 USD from her business. She is requesting a loan of 400 USD in order to purchase vitenge (African traditional clothing), shirts, children's clothes and trousers. Ndeshi thanks you for your support!

SELFINA has taken a lead role as a pioneer of microcredit in Tanzania. The organization is devoted to the economic empowerment of women in Tanzania through microfinance as a practical way to achieve the economic and social emancipation of women. Customs and traditions in Tanzania make it difficult for women to own land and assets; thus, they are deemed non-creditworthy by financial institutions. This leads to poor financial support and hence poor access to basic needs and services for women with low incomes. One of the primary advantages of microleasing is that it allows clients to use the equipment as collateral for future loans with SELFINA, enabling them to borrow larger sums in the future.

loans.use: To purchase clothing for resale

loans.name: Ayedzo

texts.fr: Ayedzo O. est un jeune homme âgé de 35 ans, marié et père de 2 enfants. Il est revendeur de motos à Atakpamé, une ville située à environ 170 kilomètres de Lomé, la capitale togolaise. Afin de sécuriser ses stocks, il souhaite avec ce crédit construire un magasin pour le stockage de ses marchandises.
texts.en:
Ayedzo O., 35, is married and the father of 2 children. He sells mopeds and motorcycles in Atakpamé, a town situated about 170 km from Lomé, the Togolese capital. So as secure his inventory, he is requesting this loan to build a storeroom where he can keep his merchandise.

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: to build a storeroom for his merchandise

loans.name: Kossiwa

texts.fr: Kossiwa K. est revendeuse de sels depuis 3 ans au grand marché d’Atakpamé, une ville située au centre du Togo. Elle exerce cette activité depuis 5 ans et souhaite avec ce crédit augmenter la capacité de son activité. Kossiwa est âgée de 35 ans, mariée et mère de 2 enfants.
texts.en:
For three years Kossiwa K. has been selling salt at the main market at Atakpamé, a town located in the centre of Togo. She has been involved in this activity for five years and wants to use the loan to increase the size of her business. Kossiwa is 35 years old, married and the mother of two children.

Translated from French by Sarah Llewellyn, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy salt for resale

loans.name: Joyce

texts.en:
Mambo from Tanzania! This is 48-year-old Joyce S. from Mwanza. She is married with four children, between the ages of 10 and 17. Joyce has been running a kuku farm since 2008.

Raising kuku is a popular micro-business in Tanzania, especially amongst SELFINA clients. Kuku means chickens in Swahili, and raising them for sale is popular for a number of reasons. First, they require little start-up capital. You can start with one or two, and either add to them as you go, or wait for them to multiply naturally! Second, they require little space, so you can sometimes just let them run around your garden or compound. Third, while they are growing they produce eggs which can either be sold to provide a supplementary source of income or eaten to provide a supplementary source of protein.

Joyce works at this kuku business for eight hours per day, seven days per week. Joyce currently earns about 200 USD from her business. She is requesting a loan of 400 USD in order to buy 200 chickens. In the future, she plans to further increase the number of her chickens. Joyce thanks you for your support!

SELFINA has taken a lead role as a pioneer of microcredit in Tanzania. The organization is devoted to the economic empowerment of women in Tanzania through microfinance as a practical way to achieve the economic and social emancipation of women. Customs and traditions in Tanzania make it difficult for women to own land and assets; thus, they are deemed non-creditworthy by financial institutions. This leads to poor financial support and hence poor access to basic needs and services for women with low incomes. One of the primary advantages of microleasing is that it allows clients to use the equipment as collateral for future loans with SELFINA, enabling them to borrow larger sums in the future.

loans.use: To purchase more chickens to raise

loans.name: Zrawarshah

texts.en:
This young man is Zrawarshah K.. He is married and the father of four children. He lives in Behsood, Jalalabad and is an educated man. He is the one active person supporting his family, and he works by farming on his land in the village.

Zrawarshah has three daughters and one son. His son is 5 years old. Zrawarshah is a working man. He grows different vegetables on his land, and he sells them in the bazaar. Now he wants to expand his business, but he needs a 40,000AF ($850 US) individual loan for 27 months to increase his business. For this, he requested that AFSG lenders give him 40,000AF so he can buy some seed and another things for his land.

He says, "Thanks Kiva lenders who support poor people in Afghanistan."

loans.use: To buy seeds and insecticide for his land.

loans.name: Latifa

texts.fr: Latifa A. est une jeune femme qui habite à Atakpamé, une à environ 170 kilomètres de Lomé, la capitale togolaise. Elle est revendeuse de produits de beauté depuis 5 ans et souhaite avec ce crédit redonner du dynamisme à son activité en alimentant sa boutique. Agée de 38 ans, elle est mariée et mère de 2 enfants.
texts.en:
Latifa A. is a young women who lives in Atakpamé, a city about 170 km from Lomé, the Togolese capital. She has been a retailer of beauty products for five years and would like to use this loan to reinvigorate her business by re-supplying her shop. She is 38 years old, married, and the mother of two.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy beauty products to resell

loans.name: Agnes

texts.en:
Mambo from Tanzania! This 39-year-old Agnes M. from Mwanza. She is married with four children between the ages of seven and 17. Agnes has been running a clothes business since 1999. She sells traditional clothing worn by Tanzanian women, called kanga and vitenge. The kanga is a piece of printed cotton fabric, often with a border along all four sides. It is printed using the silkscreen method and has its pattern in frames. Kitenge (the Swahili plural is vitenge) is a cotton fabric with wax print, printed by using rotary printing machines. Kitenge is an expressive textile: the various colors, patterns, writings and symbols represent moods, feelings, cultures, and traditions of native African people. In addition, Agnes runs a tailoring business where she can sew those fabrics purchased in her store to the specifications of her customers. She works at this business for six hours per day, 12 days per week and is assisted by her husband. Agnes currently earns about 100 USD from her business. She is requesting a loan of 400 USD in order to purchase another sewing machine. Agnes thanks you for your support!

SELFINA has taken a lead role as a pioneer of microcredit in Tanzania. The organization is devoted to the economic empowerment of women in Tanzania through microfinance as a practical way to achieve the economic and social emancipation of women. Customs and traditions in Tanzania make it difficult for women to own land and assets; thus, they are deemed non-creditworthy by financial institutions. This leads to poor financial support and hence poor access to basic needs and services for women with low incomes. One of the primary advantages of microleasing is that it allows clients to use the equipment as collateral for future loans with SELFINA, enabling them to borrow larger sums in the future.

loans.use: To purchase a sewing machine

loans.name: Janeth

texts.en:
Mambo from Tanzania! This is 32-year-old Janeth M. from Mwanza. She is married with three children between the ages of two and 10. Janeth has been running a milling machine since 2000. Farmers come from the surrounding area to provide their corn to be ground into maize. Maize is very important to the Tanzanian culture: it is used to make one of their staple dishes, ugali, which is made solely of maize flour and water. Janeth works at the business for 12 hours per day, seven days per week and is assisted by two employees. She currently earns about 50 USD from her business. She is requesting a loan of 400 USD in order to purchase large sacks to store the ground maize which she sells in bulk. Janeth thanks you for your support!

SELFINA has taken a lead role as a pioneer of microcredit in Tanzania. The organization is devoted to the economic empowerment of women in Tanzania through microfinance as a practical way to achieve the economic and social emancipation of women. Customs and traditions in Tanzania make it difficult for women to own land and assets; thus, they are deemed non-creditworthy by financial institutions. This leads to poor financial support and hence poor access to basic needs and services for women with low incomes. One of the primary advantages of microleasing is that it allows clients to use the equipment as collateral for future loans with SELFINA, enabling them to borrow larger sums in the future.

loans.use: To purchase large sacks to store ground maize

loans.name: Keramatshah

texts.en:
Keramatshah is a young boy with lots of experience. He is single and lives in Behsood, Nangrahar province. Though he is uneducated, he works in agriculture and has been involved in this business for more than 3 years, working with his family during this time. He has some land, but he would love to have more. In order to buy more seeds and some insecticide for his land, he needs extra money. Therefore, he requested an individual loan of 40,000AF ($1,000 US) for 27 months to buy some seeds and insecticide for his land.

Keramatshah is a professional, and from when he started his business, he has always wanted to improve his business. In the village where he lives, when any of the agricultural men face any difficulties, they come and ask Keramatshah to help with their problems.

He is grateful for this loan process. He wants to say that it is his first loan and that it is really great, especially for agriculture workers. He wants to continue his partnership and to encourage other workers to use this loan service.

loans.use: To purchase seeds and insecticide for his land.

loans.name: Vu Thi

texts.vi: Chị Huế năm nay 50 tuổi, gia đìnhchị có 3 con đều đã trưởng thành. Năm 1997 chị tham gia Quỹ tình thương  và vay 500.000đ để đầu tư vào chăn nuôi. Sau 6 tháng dự án cho thu nhập 1.200.000đ. Hiện nay ngoài thu nhập từ chăn nuôi lợn gà hàng tháng gia đình chị còn có thêm nguồn thu nhập từ lương  của các con nên kinh tế gia đình chị rất ổn định. Với mức thu nhập 4.000.000đ kinh tế gia đình chị Huế đang ngày càng ổn định và phát triển hơn. Vòng vốn tới chị mong muốn được vay 15.000.000đ để đầu tư sửa sang chuồng trại và mua thêm 7 con lợn về nuôi
texts.en:
Mrs Huế is 50 years old. Her familiy includes 3 already grown-up children. In 1997, she joined the Fund and borrowed 500.000đ to buy animals to breed. After 6 months, the venture provided an income of 1.200.000đ. Nowadays, besides the income from pig and chicken farming, the family's revenues have stabilized, through the additional income from all the children. With the current income of 4.000.000đ, the family Huế's economy is improving with every passing day. For the next round, she would like to borrow 15.000.000đ to refurbish the breeding facilities and buy 7 additional pigs to breed.

Translated from Vietnamese by Minh Bui, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Raising

loans.name: Dao Thi

texts.vi: Chị Đào Thị Tươi năm nay 42 tuổi, chị tham gia Quỹ tình thương từ năm 2001. Trước khi tham gia Quỹ thu nhập của gia đình chị chủ yếu dựa vào chăn nuôi trồng trọt và buôn bán gạo. Đến nay qua 7 năm tham gia Quỹ tình thương kinh tế gia đình chị đã có nhiều sự đổi thay . Với việc sử dụng vốn vay hiệu quả gia đình chị đã đầu tư mua thêm được máy sát gạo phục vụ nhu cầu của bà con địa phương. Hiện tại thu nhập của gia đình chị đạt  3.000.000đ/ tháng. Vòng vốn tới chị mong muốn được vay 9.000.000đ để đầu tư mua 2 tấn thóc phục vụ cho công việc buôn bán gạo của gia đình
texts.en:
Mrs Đào Thị Tươi is 42 years old. She joined the Fund in 2001. Before joining the Fund, the family's income was essentially relying on farming, planting vegetables and selling rice. Over the last 7 years with the Fund, the family's economy has evolved considerably. With the profits from the loans, the family was able to invest into a rice processing machine, serving the needs of the farmers in the area. Currently, the family's income is about 3.000.000đ per month. For the next round, she would like to borrow 9.000.000đ to invest into stock for the rice-selling business.

Translated from Vietnamese by Minh Bui, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Invest in Rice business

loans.name: Yawa

texts.fr: Yawa D. est propriétaire d’un bar restaurant depuis 7 ans à Atakpamé, une ville située au centre du Togo. Agée de 52 ans, elle est mariée et mère de 5 enfants. Elle espère avec ce crédit augmenter la capacité de son activité et achetant des matières première nécessaire à la restauration du « foufou » un plat conçu à base de l’igname et qui est tant appréciée par la population locale.
texts.en:
Yawa D. has owned a bar-restaurant for 7 years in Atakpamé, a city in the centre of Togo. She is 52 years old, married, and the mother of five children. She hopes to increase the capacity of her business by buying the raw materials necessary for the production of "foufou", a yam-based dish very much appreciated by the locals.

Translated from French by Laure Kwon, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy yams for her restaurant

loans.name: Le Thi

texts.vi: Chị Vượn tham gia Quỹ tình thương từ năm 2001. Trong suốt 7 năm tham gia Quỹ chị Vượn đều sử dụng vốn vay đầu tư cho chăn nuôi.  Hiện tại gia đình chị đang chăn nuôi 10 con lợn cho thu nhập 2.000.000/ tháng. Ngoài ra hàng tháng gia đình chị còn có thêm 300.000đ từ lương làm cán bộ thôn của chồng. Với mức thu nhập nay gia đình chị cũng có điều kiện để đầu tư tốt hơn cho 1 người con đang đi học. vòng vốn tới chị mong muốn được vay 9.000.000đ để đầu tư mua thêm 5 con lợn giống và thức ăn phục vụ cho chăn nuôi
texts.en:
Mrs. Vượn joined the Fund in 2001. Over the last 7 years, she regularly used the loans to invest into animal farming. Currently, her family is raising 10 pigs for a revenue of 2.000.000đ per month. There is also an additional revenue of 300.000đ from the husband's salary as village cadre. The family is considering to invest further, in order to allow one child to go to school. For the next round, she would like to borrow 9.000.000đ to buy 5 additional pigs to breed, as well as pig feed.

Translated from Vietnamese by Minh Bui, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Raising

loans.name: Jane

texts.en:
Jane A. O. lives in Rongo, Kenya, where she sells fertilizer to the rural farmers in the area. She has had a consistent supply of satisfied, repeat customers for the three years she has been in business.

Twice a week, Jane purchases 10 sacks of fertilizer from Kisii, a small town that is a 45-minute drive from Rongo. In order to save both time and money on transportation, she would like to be able to travel there just once a week and buy 20 sacks of fertilizer, the reason she is requesting a loan of $400.

Jane is the married breadwinner of a family of five, two members of whom are disabled and require extra support. Jane maintains her sense of humor even in a difficult situation, humbly and laughingly referring to herself as “just a local woman jumbling around town, trying to make some money.”

loans.use: To purchase more fertilizer.

loans.name: Duong Thi

texts.vi: Chị Thuý năm nay 32 tuổi, chị đang sống cùng chồng và hai con tại xã Yên Bình, huyện ý Yên tỉnh Nam Định. Gia đình chị có nghề buôn bán thịt lợn. Hiện nay mỗi ngày hai vợ chồng chị mổ hai con lợn cung cấp thực phẩm cho người dân địa phương cho thu nhập từ 100.000d đến 200.000đ/ ngày. Vòng vố tới chị mong muốn được vay 9.000.000 đ để đầu tư vốn cho công việc buôn bán thịt lợn của  gia đình
texts.en:
Mrs Thuý is 32 years old. She lives with her husband and two boys in the village of Yên Bình, in the Nam Định province. The family's occupation is to sell pork meat. Currently, husband and wife dissects two pigs every day to supply meat to local people, for a revenue of 100.000d to 200.000đ per day. For the next round, she would like to borrow 9.000.000đ to invest into their meat-selling business.

Translated from Vietnamese by Minh Bui, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Business

loans.name: Vu Thi

texts.vi: Chị Vũ Thị Tuyết năm nay 51 tuổi, chị mới tham gia Quỹ tình thương được hơn 1 năm.Hiện nay  chị  bán hàng ăn ở chợ còn chồng chị hàng ngày giúp chị chế biến thức ăn và đi lấy hàng về để chị bán. Tuy mới tham gia vào Quỹ, chỉ với mức vốn vay ban đầu  5 triệu đồng nhưng  đã giúp cho gia đình chị có thu nhập cao hơn. Với mức thu nhập 2 triệu đồng/ tháng cũng đủ để gia đình chị  đảm bảo hoàn trả đầy đủ và cải thiện chát lượng cuậc sống. Vòng vốn tới chị mong muốn được vay 9 triệu đồng để mua bàn ghế, thực phẩm phục vụ cho công việc bán hàng ăn.
texts.en:
Mrs. T. Thi Vu, 51 years old, has just joined the Fund for a little more than a year. Currently she is running a street food stall at the local market, and her husband helps with preparing the food as well as bringing the raw ingredients home. Although she has just joined the Fund, she borrowed the loan limit of 5 million VND which helped her family increase their income. With an income of 2 million VND/month, the family can guarantee that they will be able to repay the loan as well as improve their standard of living. In this coming round of funding, she would like to borrow 9 million VND to buy chairs and tables and raw foods to use in their food stall business.

Translated from Vietnamese by Chi Nguyen, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy tables and chairs, foods
